Accessed 14 Oct 2020.","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.3390/nu12061583","date":"2020-05-25","title":"Effects of COVID-19 Home Confinement on Eating Behaviour and Physical Activity: Results of the ECLB-COVID19 International Online Survey","abstract":"Background: Public health recommendations and governmental measures during the COVID-19 pandemic have resulted in numerous restrictions on daily living including social distancing, isolation and home confinement.\n While these measures are imperative to abate the spreading of COVID-19, the impact of these restrictions on health behaviours and lifestyles at home is undefined.\n Therefore, an international online survey was launched in April 2020, in seven languages, to elucidate the behavioural and lifestyle consequences of COVID-19 restrictions.\n This report presents the results from the first thousand responders on physical activity (PA) and nutrition behaviours.\n Methods: Following a structured review of the literature, the “Effects of home Confinement on multiple Lifestyle Behaviours during the COVID-19 outbreak (ECLB-COVID19)” Electronic survey was designed by a steering group of multidisciplinary scientists and academics.\n The survey was uploaded and shared on the Google online survey platform.\n Thirty-five research organisations from Europe, North-Africa, Western Asia and the Americas promoted the survey in English, German, French, Arabic, Spanish, Portuguese and Slovenian languages.\n Questions were presented in a differential format, with questions related to responses “before” and “during” confinement conditions.\n Results: 1047 replies (54% women) from Asia (36%), Africa (40%), Europe (21%) and other (3%) were included in the analysis.\n The COVID-19 home confinement had a negative effect on all PA intensity levels (vigorous, moderate, walking and overall).\n Additionally, daily sitting time increased from 5 to 8 h per day.\n Food consumption and meal patterns (the type of food, eating out of control, snacks between meals, number of main meals) were more unhealthy during confinement, with only alcohol binge drinking decreasing significantly.\n Conclusion: While isolation is a necessary measure to protect public health, results indicate that it alters physical activity and eating behaviours in a health compromising direction.\n A more detailed analysis of survey data will allow for a segregation of these responses in different age groups, countries and other subgroups, which will help develop interventions to mitigate the negative lifestyle behaviours that have manifested during the COVID-19 confinement.\n","id":"PMC7352706","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Achraf","surname":"Ammar","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Michael","surname":"Brach","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Michael","surname":"Brach","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Khaled","surname":"Trabelsi","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Hamdi","surname":"Chtourou","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Omar","surname":"Boukhris","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Liwa","surname":"Masmoudi","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Bassem","surname":"Bouaziz","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Ellen","surname":"Bentlage","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Daniella","surname":"How","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Mona","surname":"Ahmed","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Mona","surname":"Ahmed","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Patrick","surname":"Müller","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Notger","surname":"Müller","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Asma","surname":"Aloui","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Omar","surname":"Hammouda","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Laisa UCLA CCPR Population Working Papers.","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0057646","date":"2013-01-24","title":"Socioeconomic and Geographic Patterning of Smoking Behaviour in Canada: A Cross-Sectional Multilevel Analysis","abstract":"Objective\nTo describe the socioeconomic and geographic distribution of smoking behaviour in Canada among 19,383 individuals (51% women) aged 15–85 years.\n\n\nMethods\nCurrent smoking and quitting were modeled using standard and multilevel logistic regression.\n\n Markers of socioeconomic status (SES) were education and occupation.\n\n Geography was defined by Canadian Provinces.\n\n\nResults\nThe adjusted prevalence of current smoking was 20.2% (95% confidence interval [CI]: 18.8–21.7) and 63.7% (95% CI: 61.1–66.3) of ever smokers had quit.\n\n Current smoking decreased and quitting increased with increasing SES.\n\n The adjusted prevalence of current smoking was 32.8% (95% CI: 28.4–37.5) among the least educated compared to 11.0% (95% CI: 8.9–13.4) for the highest educated.\n\n Among the least educated, 53.0% (95% CI: 46.8–59.2) had quit, rising to 68.7% (95% CI: 62.7–74.1) for the most educated.\n\n There was substantial variation in current smoking and quitting at the provincial level; current smoking varied from 17.9% in British Columbia to 26.1% in Nova Scotia, and quitting varied from 57.4% in Nova Scotia to 67.8% in Prince Edward Island.\n\n Nationally, increasing education and occupation level were inversely associated with current smoking (odds ratio [OR] 0.64, 95% CI: 0.60–0.68 for education; OR 0.82, 95% CI: 0.77–0.87 for occupation) and positively associated with quitting (OR 1.27, 95% CI: 1.16–1.40 for education; OR 1.20, 95% CI: 1.12–1.27 for occupation).\n\n These associations were consistent in direction across provinces although with some variability in magnitude.\n\n\nConclusion\nOur findings indicate that socioeconomic inequalities in smoking have persisted in Canada; current smoking was less likely and quitting was more likely among the better off groups and in certain provinces.\n\n Current prevention and cessation policies have not been successful in improving the situation for all areas and groups.\n\n Future efforts to reduce smoking uptake and increase cessation in Canada will need consideration of socioeconomic and geographic factors to be successful.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3585192","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Daniel J.","surname":"Corsi","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Scott A.","surname":"Lear","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Clara K.","surname":"Chow","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"S. 0.001) but this was not seen in the active population.\n Inactive participants who spent more time engaged in outdoor physical activity had lower anxiety than those who spent less time in outdoor physical activity.\n Public health measures differentially affected Canadians who were active and inactive and physical activity was strongly associated with well-being outcomes in inactive individuals.\n This suggests that health promoting measures directed towards inactive individuals may be essential to improving well-being.\n","id":"PMC7312579","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Iris A.","surname":"Lesser","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Carl P.","surname":"Nienhuis","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1016/s0140-6736(12)61766-8","date":"1970-01-01","title":"A comparative risk assessment of burden of disease and injury attributable to 67 risk factors and risk factor clusters in 21 regions, 1990-2010: a systematic analysis for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2010","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"NULL","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Lopez-Bueno, R., Calatayud, J., Casana, J., Casajus, J. gender gap","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/s12889-019-7674-4","date":"2019-09-23","title":"The relationships between health-related behaviours in the Canadian adult population","abstract":"Background\nid='Par1'>Health-related behaviours such as physical inactivity, low fruit and vegetable intake, smoking, alcohol use, and inadequate sleep are significant predictors of adverse health outcomes.\n\n Health promotion strategies often focus on one behavior, though research suggests health-related behaviours tend to co-occur.\n\n The purpose of this study is to describe the relationships between health-related behaviours in the Canadian adult population.\n\n\nMethods\nid='Par2'>Data from cycles 3 (2012–2013) and 4 (2014–2015) of the Canadian Health Measures Survey were pooled to describe health-related behaviours (current smoking status, high-risk alcohol use, fruit and vegetable intake, inadequate sleep, and physical activity) among adults according to sex, age group, household education, and income adequacy.\n\n Logistic regression was used to test for relationships between health-related behaviours.\n\n\nResults\nid='Par3'>Findings indicated that adverse health-related behaviours co-occur frequently, with approximately half of Canadians reporting two or more adverse health-related behaviours.\n\n Overall, Canadian men were more likely to report adverse health-related behaviours compared to women, with the exception of inadequate sleep.\n\n Smoking status, fruit and vegetable intake, sleep and physical activity exhibited an income and education gradient.\n\n Sex-based patterns in grouping of behaviours were present such that adverse health-related behaviours were associated with current smoking among men and with high-risk alcohol use among women.\n\n\nConclusion\nid='Par4'>Our findings suggest that health-related behaviours should be considered in both isolation and combination when designing intervention strategies.\n\n Sex-specific patterns of how these behaviours co-occur must also be taken into account.\n\n\n","id":"PMC6814028","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Adriana and Italy: what next?","abstract":"The spread of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) has already taken on pandemic proportions, affecting over 100 countries in a matter of weeks.\n A global response to prepare health systems worldwide is imperative.\n Although containment measures in China have reduced new cases by more than 90%, this reduction is not the case elsewhere, and Italy has been particularly affected.\n There is now grave concern regarding the Italian national health system's capacity to effectively respond to the needs of patients who are infected and require intensive care for SARS-CoV-2 pneumonia.\n The percentage of patients in intensive care reported daily in Italy between March 1 and March 11, 2020, has consistently been between 9% and 11% of patients who are actively infected.\n The number of patients infected since Feb 21 in Italy closely follows an exponential trend.\n If this trend continues for 1 more week, there will be 30?000 infected patients.\n Intensive care units will then be at maximum capacity; up to 4000 hospital beds will be needed by mid-April, 2020. Our analysis might help political leaders and health authorities to allocate enough resources, including personnel, beds, and intensive care facilities, to manage the situation in the next few days and weeks.\n If the Italian outbreak follows a similar trend as in Hubei province, China, the number of newly infected patients could start to decrease within 3–4 days, departing from the exponential trend.\n However, this cannot currently be predicted because of differences between social distancing measures and the capacity to quickly build dedicated facilities in China.\n","id":"PMC7102589","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Andrea","surname":"Remuzzi","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Giuseppe","surname":"Remuzzi","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"NULL","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Roterman, M. twenty-first century.\n As of 1 March 2020, a total of 87,137 confirmed cases globally, 79,968 confirmed in China and 7169 outside of China, with 2977 deaths (3.4%) had been reported by WHO.\n novel coronavirus uses the same receptor, angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) as that for SARS-CoV, and mainly spreads through the respiratory tract.\n Importantly, increasingly evidence showed respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and cytokine storm.\n Currently, there are few specific antiviral strategies, but several potent candidates of antivirals and repurposed drugs are under urgent investigation.\n In this review, we summarized the latest research progress of the epidemiology, pathogenesis, and clinical characteristics of COVID-19, and discussed the current treatment and Implications for the Diagnosis and Treatment of Overeating","abstract":"With the obesity epidemic being largely attributed to overeating, much research has been aimed at understanding the psychological causes of overeating and using this knowledge to develop targeted interventions.\n Here, we review this literature under a model of food addiction and present evidence according to the fifth edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual (DSM-5) criteria for substance use disorders.\n We review several innovative treatments related to a food addiction model ranging from cognitive intervention tasks to neuromodulation techniques.\n We conclude that there is evidence to suggest that, for some individuals, food can induce addictive-type behaviours similar to those seen with other addictive substances.\n However, with several DSM-5 criteria having limited application to overeating, the term ‘food addiction’ is likely to apply only in a minority of cases.\n Nevertheless, research investigating the underlying psychological causes of overeating within the context of food addiction has led to some novel and potentially effective interventions.\n Understanding the similarities and differences between the addictive characteristics of food and illicit substances should prove fruitful in further developing these absorption) with drugs of abuse, due to the addition of fat and/or refined carbohydrates and the rapid rate the refined carbohydrates are absorbed into the system, indicated by glycemic load (GL).\n\n (Study Two).\n\n\nParticipants\n120 undergraduates participated in Study One and 384 participants recruited through Amazon MTurk participated in Study Two.\n\n\nMeasurements\nIn Study One, participants (n = 120) completed the Yale Food Addiction Scale (YFAS) followed by a forced-choice task to indicate which foods, out of 35 foods varying in nutritional composition, were most associated with addictive-like eating behaviors.\n\n Using the same 35 foods, Study Two utilized hierarchical linear modeling to investigate which food attributes (e.\n\ng.\n\n, fat grams) were related to addictive-like eating behavior (at level one) and explored the influence of individual differences for this association (at level two).\n\n\nResults\nIn Study One, processed foods, higher in fat and GL, were most frequently associated with addictive-like eating behaviors.\n\n In Study Two, processing was a large, positive predictor for whether a food was associated with problematic, addictive-like eating behaviors.\n\n BMI and YFAS symptom count were small-to-moderate, positive predictors for this association.\n\n In a separate model, fat and GL were large, positive predictors of problematic food ratings.\n\n YFAS symptom count was a small, positive predictor of the relationship between GL and food ratings.\n\n\nConclusion\nThe current study provides preliminary evidence that Moreover, gambling disorder is now included along SUDs as a behavioral addiction.\n Although a plethora of review articles exist that discuss the applicability of the DSM-IV substance dependence criteria to eating behavior, the transferability of the newly added criteria to eating is unknown.\n Thus, the current article discusses if and how these new criteria may be translated to overeating.\n Furthermore, it is examined if the new SUD criteria will impact future research on food addiction, for example, if “diagnosing” food addiction should also be adapted by considering all of the new symptoms.\n Given the critical response to the revisions in DSM-5, we also discuss if the recent approach of Research Domain Criteria can be helpful in evaluating the concept of food Stigma, and Policy Implications of Food Addiction: A Scoping Review","abstract":"The concept of food addiction has generated much controversy.\n In comparison to research examining the construct of food addiction and its validity, relatively little research has examined the broader implications of food addiction.\n The purpose of the current scoping review was to examine the potential ethical, stigma, and health policy implications of food addiction.\n Major themes were identified in the literature, and extensive overlap was identified between several of the themes.\n Ethics sub-themes related primarily to individual responsibility and included: (i) personal control, will power, and choice; and (ii) blame and weight bias.\n Stigma sub-themes included: (i) the impact on self-stigma and stigma from others, (ii) the differential impact of substance use disorder versus behavioral addiction on stigma, and (iii) the additive stigma of addiction plus obesity and/or eating disorder.\n Policy implications were broadly derived from comparisons to the tobacco industry and focused on addictive foods as opposed to food addiction.\n This scoping review underscored the need for increased awareness of food addiction and the role of the food industry, empirical research to identify specific hyperpalatable food substances, and policy interventions that are not simply extrapolated from tobacco.\n","id":"PMC6521112","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Stephanie E.","surname":"Cassin","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Daniel Use in a Non-Clinical Sample of Women over Two Years","abstract":"(1) Background: With the new edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental disorders, 5th Edition (DSM-5), numerous parallels have been drawn between recurrent binge eating (RBE) and substance use disorders, with many authors examining RBE or binge eating disorder (BED) as a “food addiction”.\n The present study aims to clarify the relationship between recurrent binge eating (RBE) and illicit substance use (ISU) through investigating the temporal association between the two problems.\n (2) Methods: This study was embedded within a larger longitudinal study of non-clinical adult women recruited from Australian tertiary institutions.\n Participants responded at year 2 and year 4 of follow-up to the Eating Disorder Examination—Questionnaire.\n ISU was measured using a modified questionnaire taken from the Australian Longitudinal Study on Women’s Health.\n (3) Results: RBE and ISU co-morbidity was 5.88% in this non-clinical sample, and having one condition increased the likelihood of the other.\n The two conditions had a different trajectory over two years whereby ISU participants had significant risk of developing RBE in addition to or in place of their ISU but the reverse was not found for RBE participants.\n (4) Conclusion: This unidirectional relationship suggests that in spite of the was an education in portion size&quot;. Experience of eating a healthy diet and barriers to long term dietary change","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/1475-2891-10-9","date":"2011-01-24","title":"Weight Science: Evaluating the Evidence for a Paradigm Shift","abstract":"Current guidelines recommend that 'overweight' and 'obese' individuals lose weight through engaging in lifestyle modification involving diet, exercise and other behavior change.\n This approach reliably induces short term weight loss, but the majority of individuals are unable to maintain weight loss over the long term and do not achieve the putative benefits of improved morbidity and mortality.\n Concern has arisen that this weight focus is not only ineffective at producing thinner, healthier bodies, but may also have unintended consequences, contributing to food and body preoccupation, repeated cycles of weight loss and regain, distraction from other personal health goals and wider health determinants, reduced self-esteem, eating disorders, other health decrement, and weight stigmatization and discrimination.\n This concern has drawn increased attention to the ethical implications of recommending treatment that may be ineffective or damaging.\n A growing trans-disciplinary movement called Health at Every Size (HAES) challenges the value of promoting weight loss and dieting behavior and argues for a shift in focus to weight-neutral outcomes.\n Randomized controlled clinical trials indicate that a HAES approach is associated with statistically and clinically relevant improvements in physiological measures (e.\ng.\n, blood pressure, blood lipids), health behaviors (e.\ng.\n, eating and activity habits, dietary quality), and psychosocial outcomes (such as self-esteem and body image), and that HAES achieves these health outcomes more successfully than weight loss treatment and without the contraindications associated with a weight focus.\n This paper evaluates the evidence and rationale that justifies shifting the health care Distinctive Trait of Severe Cocaine Addiction among Individuals Treated for Cocaine or Alcohol Use Disorders","abstract":"Aims\nDespite alcohol being the most often used addictive substance among addicted patients, use of other substances such as cocaine has increased over recent years, and the combination of both drugs aggravates health impairment and complicates clinical assessment.\n\n The aim of this study is to identify and characterize heterogeneous subgroups of cocaine- and alcohol-addicted patients with common characteristics based on substance use disorders, psychiatric comorbidity and impulsivity.\n\n\nMethods\nA total of 214 subjects with cocaine and/or alcohol use disorders were recruited from outpatient treatment programs and clinically assessed.\n\n A latent class analysis was used to establish phenotypic categories according to diagnosis of cocaine and alcohol use disorders, mental disorders, and impulsivity scores.\n\n Relevant variables were examined in the latent classes (LCs) using correlation and analyses of variance and covariance.\n\n\nResults\nFour LCs of addicted patients were identified: Class 1 (45.3%) formed by alcohol-dependent patients exhibiting lifetime mood disorder diagnosis and mild impulsivity; Class 2 (14%) formed mainly by lifetime cocaine use disorder patients with low probability of comorbid mental disorders and mild impulsivity; Class 3 (10.7%) formed by cocaine use disorder patients with elevated probability to course with lifetime anxiety, early and personality disorders, and greater impulsivity scores; and Class 4 (29.9%) formed mainly by patients with alcohol and cocaine use disorders, with elevated probability in early and personality disorders and elevated impulsivity.\n\n Furthermore, there were significant differences among classes in terms of Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders-4th Edition-Text Revision criteria for abuse and dependence: Class 3 showed more criteria for cocaine use disorders than other classes, while Class 1 and Class 4 showed more criteria for alcohol use disorders.\n\n\nConclusion\nCocaine- and alcohol-addicted patients who were grouped according to diagnosis of substance use disorders, psychiatric comorbidity, and impulsivity show different clinical and sociodemographic variables.\n\n Whereas mood and anxiety disorders are more prevalent in alcohol-addicted patients, personality disorders are associated with cocaine use disorders and diagnosis of comorbid substance use disorders.\n\n Notably, increased impulsivity is a distinctive characteristic of patients with severe cocaine use disorder and comorbid personality disorders.\n\n Psychiatric disorders and impulsivity should be considered for improving the stratification of addicted patients with shared clinical and sociodemographic characteristics to select more appropriate treatments.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5817335","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Nuria","surname":"García-Marchena","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"David","surname":"Ladrón gambling","abstract":"Introduction\nImpulsivity is a central feature of drug addiction and may arise as a result of impaired inhibitory control.\n\n The extent to which inhibitory deficits arise as a consequence of drug exposure or relate to pre-existing addiction vulnerability is unknown.\n\n\nMaterials and methods\nThis study compared measures of impulsivity in outpatients with alcohol dependence (n?=?23) and problem gambling (n?=?21), a putative behavioural addiction where direct effects of drug exposure may be minimal.\n\n Healthy controls (n?=?27) were also tested, in a cross-sectional design.\n\n Subjects completed the stop-signal test as a neurocognitive probe of response inhibition, alongside self-report ratings of impulsivity, adult ADHD and OCD.\n\n\nResults\nOn the stop-signal test, Go reaction time and stop-signal reaction time were significantly slower in the alcohol-dependent group, compared with healthy controls.\n\n Healthy controls slowed their responding after successful and failed stop trials.\n\n Slowing after failed stop trials was significantly attenuated in the alcohol-dependent subjects.\n\n Go reaction time and post-error slowing were correlated with chronicity and severity, respectively, in the alcohol-dependent subjects.\n\n Problem gamblers did not differ significantly from controls on the stop-signal test, despite trait elevations in impulsivity ratings.\n\n\nConclusion\nInhibitory control is impaired in alcohol dependence but occurs in the context of psychomotor slowing.\n\n In addition, alcohol-dependent individuals failed to show behavioral adjustment following failed stops.\n\n These deficits may represent direct effects of chronic alcohol administration on fronto-striatal circuitry.\n\n\n","id":"PMC2764851","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Andrew adolescents’ unhealthy snacking and drinking behavior, mechanisms explaining these associations remain to be explored.\n\n The present study will therefore examine whether the associations between SR and unhealthy snack and/or sugar-sweetened beverage (SSB) intake are mediated by external and/or emotional eating and if this mediation is moderated by availability at home or at school.\n\n\nMethods\nCross-sectional data on snacking, availability of snacks at home and at school, SR (BAS drive scale) and external and emotional eating (Dutch eating behavior questionnaire) of Flemish adolescents (n?=?1104, mean age?=?14.7?±?0.8 years; 51 % boys; 18.0 % overweight) in 20 schools spread across Flanders were collected.\n\n Moderated mediation analyses were conducted using generalized structural equation modeling in three steps: (1) direct association between SR and unhealthy snack or SSB intake, (2) mediation of either external or emotional eating and (3) interaction of home or school availability and emotional or external eating.\n\n\nResults\nPartial mediation of external eating (a*b?=?0.69, p?&lt;?0.05) and of emotional eating (a*b?=?0.92, p?&lt;?0.01) in the relation between SR and intake of unhealthy snacks was found (step 2).\n\n The relation between SR and SSB intake was not mediated by external or emotional eating (step 2).\n\n No moderation effects of home or school availability were found (step 3).\n\n\nConclusion\nOur findings indicate that the association between SR and the consumption of unhealthy snacks is partially explained by external and emotional eating in a population-based sample of adolescents irrespective of the home or school availability of these foods.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4748632","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Nathalie","surname":"De between individuals with and without “food addiction” with high sensitivity (85%) and specificity (93%).\n\n\nConclusions\nFCQ-T-r scores of 50 and higher may indicate clinically relevant levels of are highly sensitive to conditioned cues, whether they signal food or drugs.\n\n Are certain humans also more reactive to both food and drug cues?\nMethods\nWe examined cue-induced craving for both cigarettes and food, in the same individuals (n?=?15 adult smokers).\n\n Subjects viewed smoking-related or food-related images after abstaining from either smoking or eating.\n\n\nResults\nCertain individuals reported strong cue-induced craving after both smoking and food cues.\n\n That is, subjects who reported strong cue-induced craving for cigarettes also rated stronger cue-induced food craving.\n\n\nConclusions\nIn humans, like in nonhumans, there may be a “cue-reactive” phenotype, consisting of individuals who are highly sensitive to conditioned stimuli.\n\n This finding extends binge-eating disorder","abstract":"Individuals with bulimia nervosa (BN) or binge-eating disorder (BED) experience more frequent and intense food cravings than individuals without binge eating.\n However, it is currently unclear whether they also show larger food cue-induced increases in craving (i.\ne.\n, food cue reactivity) than those without binge eating, as suggested by conditioning theories of binge eating.\n A group of individuals with BN or BED (binge-eating group, n = 27) and a group of individuals with low trait food craving scores and without binge eating (control group, n = 19) reported their current food craving before and after a food cue exposure.\n Although food craving intensity significantly increased in both groups, this increase was significantly stronger in the binge-eating group than in the control group.\n This result is in line with conditioning models of binge eating that propose that food cues are conditioned stimuli that elicit a conditioned response (e.\ng.\n, food craving) and that this association is stronger in individuals with binge eating.\n As food craving increased in individuals with low trait food craving scores as well—although to a lesser extent—previous null results might be explained by methodological considerations such as not screening control participants for trait food Adolescent Males and Females- A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Longitudinal Studies","abstract":"Adolescent obesity and depression are increasingly prevalent and are currently recognised as major public health concerns worldwide.\n The aim of this study is to evaluate the bi-directional associations between obesity and depression in adolescents using longitudinal studies.\n A systematic literature search was conducted using Pubmed (including Medline), PsycINFO, Embase, CINAHL, BIOSIS Preview and the Cochrane Library databases.\n According to the inclusion criteria, 13 studies were found where seven studies evaluated depression leading to obesity and six other studies examined obesity leading to depression.\n Using a bias-adjusted quality effects model for the meta-analysis, we found that adolescents who were depressed had a 70% (RR 1.70, 95% CI: 1.40, 2.07) increased risk of being obese, conversely obese adolescents had an increased risk of 40% (RR 1.40, 95% CI: 1.16, 1.70) of being depressed.\n The risk difference (RD) of early adolescent depression leading to obesity is 3% higher risk than it is for obesity leading to depression.\n In sensitivity analysis, the association between depression leading to obesity was greater than that of obesity leading to depression for females in early adulthood compared with females in late adolescence.\n Overall, the findings of this study suggest a bi-directional association between depression and obesity that was stronger for female adolescents.\n However, this finding also underscores the importance of early detection and treatment strategies to inhibit the development of reciprocal disorders.\n","id":"PMC4902254","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Munim","surname":"Mannan","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Abdullah","surname":"Mamun","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Suhail","surname":"Doi","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Alexandra","surname":"Clavarino","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Judith","surname":"Homberg","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Judith","surname":"Homberg","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1001/jama.289.1.76","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Prevalence sugar consumption in early childhood","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1016/S0140-6736(10)61303-7","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Oral sucrose as an analgesic drug for procedural pain in newborn infants: a randomised controlled trial","abstract":"Background\nMany infants admitted to hospital undergo repeated invasive procedures.\n\n Oral sucrose is frequently given to relieve procedural pain in neonates on the basis of its effect on behavioural and physiological pain scores.\n\n We assessed whether sucrose administration reduces pain-specific brain and spinal cord activity after an acute noxious procedure in newborn infants.\n\n\nMethods\nIn this double-blind, randomised controlled trial, 59 newborn infants at University College Hospital (London, UK) were randomly assigned to receive 0·5 mL 24% sucrose solution or 0·5 mL sterile water 2 min before undergoing a clinically required heel lance.\n\n Randomisation was by a computer-generated randomisation code, and researchers, clinicians, participants, and parents were masked to the identity of the solutions.\n\n The primary outcome was pain-specific brain activity evoked by one time-locked heel lance, recorded with electroencephalography and identified by principal component analysis.\n\n Secondary measures were baseline behavioural and physiological measures, observational pain scores (PIPP), and spinal nociceptive reflex withdrawal activity.\n\n Data were analysed per protocol.\n\n This study is registered, number ISRCTN78390996.\nFindings\n29 infants were assigned to receive sucrose and 30 to sterilised water; 20 and 24 infants, respectively, were included in the analysis of the primary outcome measure.\n\n Nociceptive brain activity after the noxious heel lance did not differ significantly between infants who received sucrose and those who received sterile water (sucrose: mean 0·10, 95% CI 0·04–0·16; sterile water: mean 0·08, 0·04–0·12; p=0·46).\n\n No significant difference was recorded between the sucrose and sterile water groups in the magnitude or latency of the spinal nociceptive reflex withdrawal recorded from the biceps femoris of the stimulated leg.\n\n The PIPP score was significantly lower in infants given sucrose than in those given sterile water (mean 5·8, 95% CI 3·7–7·8 vs 8·5, 7·3–9·8; p=0·02) and significantly more infants had no change in facial expression after sucrose administration (seven of 20 [35%] vs none of 24; p&lt;0·0001).\n\n\nInterpretation\nOur data suggest that oral sucrose does not significantly affect activity in neonatal brain or spinal cord nociceptive circuits, and therefore might not be an effective analgesic drug.\n\n The ability of sucrose to reduce clinical observational scores after noxious events in newborn infants should not be interpreted as pain relief.\n\n\nFunding\nMedical Research Council.\n\n\n","id":"PMC2958259","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Rebeccah","surname":"Slater","email":"r.slater@ucl.ac.uk","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Laura","surname":"Cornelissen","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Lorenzo","surname":"Fabrizi","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Debbie","surname":"Patten","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jan","surname":"Yoxen","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Alan","surname":"Worley","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Stewart","surname":"Boyd","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Judith","surname":"Meek","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Maria","surname":"Fitzgerald","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1001/jama.289.4.450","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Patterns reward dysfunction and compulsive eating in obese rats: Role for dopamine D2 receptors","abstract":"id='P1'>We found that development of obesity was coupled with the emergence of a progressively worsening brain reward deficit.\n Similar changes in reward homeostasis induced by cocaine or heroin is considered a critical trigger in the transition from casual to compulsive drug-taking.\n Accordingly, we detected compulsive-like feeding behavior in obese but not lean rats, measured as palatable food consumption that was resistant to disruption by an aversive conditioned stimulus.\n Striatal dopamine D2 receptors (D2R) were downregulated in obese rats, similar to previous reports in human drug addicts.\n Moreover, lentivirus-mediated knockdown of striatal D2R rapidly accelerated the development of addiction-like reward deficits and the onset of compulsive-like food seeking in rats with extended access to palatable high-fat food.\n These data demonstrate that overconsumption of palatable food triggers addiction-like neuroadaptive responses in brain reward circuitries and drives the development of compulsive eating.\n Common hedonic mechanisms may therefore underlie and own incidental observations","abstract":"There is increasing evidence for a role of dopamine in the development of obesity.\n More specifically, dopaminergic hypofunction might lead to (over)compensatory food intake.\n Overeating and resulting weight gain may be induced by genetic predisposition for lower dopaminergic activity, but might also be a behavioral mechanism of compensating for decreased dopamine signaling after dopaminergic overstimulation, for example after smoking cessation or overconsumption of high palatable food.\n This hypothesis is in line with our incidental finding of increased weight gain after discontinuation of pharmaceutical dopaminergic overstimulation in rats.\n These findings support the crucial role of dopaminergic signaling for eating behaviors and offer an explanation for weight-gain after cessation of activities associated with high dopaminergic signaling.\n They further support the possibility that dopaminergic medication could be used to moderate food found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1136/bmjopen-2011-000175","date":"2011-08-04","title":"Obesity, orbitofrontal structure and function are associated with food choice: a cross-sectional study","abstract":"Objectives\nObesity is on the rise in the US and is linked to the development of type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease.\n\n Emerging evidence over the last decade suggests that obesity may also adversely affect executive function and brain structure.\n\n Although a great deal of research focuses on how diet affects the brain and cognitive performance, no study focuses on how food choice may be associated with brain integrity.\n\n Here we investigated how lean and overweight/obese (o/o) adults differed in their food choices and how brain structure and cognition may be associated with those choices.\n\n\nDesign\nAs part of an ongoing study on diabetes and the brain, participants had routine blood work and a research MRI, received a battery of neurocognitive tests, and were instructed to keep a 3-day food diary.\n\n\nResults and conclusions\nThe lean group ate more high quality foods and less low quality foods compared to the o/o group.\n\n In the o/o group, high quality food choices were associated with orbitofrontal cortex volume.\n\n The lean group performed better than the o/o group on neurocognitive measures of executive function, such as the Stroop Interference Test, the Wisconsin Card Sort Test and the Trail Making Test B-A, and on attention and concentration tasks such as the Digit Symbol Substitution Test.\n\n Taken together, these preliminary data suggest that in obesity poor food choices may be associated with frontal cognitive impairments that may be the result of, or contribute to, decreases in orbitofrontal cortex volume.\n\n Therefore, longitudinal studies are warranted to investigate a causal link between food choice and executive functioning.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3191593","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Jessica I","surname":"Cohen","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Kathy found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1038/ijo.2013.39","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Cognitive regulation of food craving: Effects of three cognitive reappraisal strategies on neural response to palatable foods","abstract":"Objective\nid='P1'>Obese versus lean individuals show greater reward region and reduced inhibitory region responsivity to food images, which predict future weight gain.\n\n Thinking of the costs of eating palatable foods and craving suppression have been found to modulate this neural responsivity, but these cognitive reappraisal studies have primarily involved lean participants.\n\n Herein we evaluated the efficacy of a broader range of reappraisal strategies in modulating neural responsivity to palatable food images among individuals who ranged from lean to obese and tested whether Body Mass Index (BMI) moderates the effects of these strategies.\n\n\nMaterials and method\nid='P2'>functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) assessed the effects of three cognitive reappraisal strategies in response to palatable food images versus an imagined intake comparison condition in a sample of adolescents (N = 21; M age = 15.2).\n\n\nResults\nid='P3'>Thinking of the long-term costs of eating the food, thinking of the long-term benefits of not eating the food, and attempting to suppress cravings for the food increased activation in inhibitory regions (e.\n\ng.\n\n, superior frontal gyrus, ventrolateral prefrontal cortex) and reduced activation in attention-related regions (e.\n\ng.\n\n, precuneus, and posterior cingulate cortex).\n\n The reappraisal strategy focusing on the long-term benefits of not eating the food more effectively increased inhibitory region activity and reduced attention region activity compared to the other two cognitive reappraisal strategies.\n\n BMI did not moderate the effects.\n\n\nDiscussion\nid='P4'>These novel results imply that cognitive reappraisal strategies, in particular those focusing on the benefits of not eating the food, could potentially increase the ability to inhibit appetitive motivation and reduce unhealthy food intake in overweight individuals.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3709002","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Sonja","surname":"Yokum","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Eric","surname":"Stice","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1038/nn1584","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Decision impulsivity has revealed an array of ambiguous findings.\n\n This may be a result of limitations to self-report assessments of impulsivity.\n\n Behavioral measures that assess more narrowly defined aspects of impulsivity may clarify genetic influences.\n\n This study examined the relationship between possession of the DRD2 TaqI A and DRD4 48 bp VNTR genetic polymorphisms and performance on a behavioral measure of impulsivity, the delay discounting task (DDT), and three traditional self-report measures.\n\n\nMethods\n195 individuals (42% male) were recruited from a university campus and were assessed in small group sessions using personal computers.\n\n Genotyping was conducted using previously established protocols.\n\n For the DRD2 TaqI A locus, individuals were designated as possessing at least one copy of the A1 allele (A1+) or not (A1-), and for the DRD4 48-bp VNTR locus, individuals were designated as having at least one long allele (7 repeats or longer, L+) or not (L-).\n\n Principal analyses used multiple univariate factorial 2 (A1+/A1-) × 2 (L+/L-) analyses of variance.\n\n\nResults\nA significant main effect of A1+ status on DDT performance was evident (p = .\n\n006) as well as a significant interaction effect (p = .\n\n006) between both genes.\n\n No other significant effects were evident on the self-report measures, with the exception of a trend toward an interaction effect on the Sensation Seeking Scale.\n\n Exploratory analyses suggested that the significant effects were not a function of population stratification or gender.\n\n\nDiscussion\nThese data suggest that the DRD2 TaqI A and DRD4 VNTR polymorphisms influence impulsivity as measured with a delay discounting task.\n\n Specifically, these findings suggest that an interaction between the functional effects of the two unlinked genotypes results in significant difference in the balance of mesolimbic dopaminergic activation relative to frontal-parietal activation.\n\n However, these findings are also the first in this area and must be replicated.\n\n\nConclusion\nThese findings suggest a meaningful interaction between the DRD2 TaqI A and DRD4 VNTR polymorphisms in the expression of impulsivity and provide initial support for the utility of using behavioral measures for clarifying genetic influences on impulsivity.\n\n\n","id":"PMC1781951","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Dan Prevalence of Food Addiction as Assessed by the Yale Food Addiction Scale: A Systematic Review","abstract":"Obesity is a global issue and it has been suggested that an addiction to certain foods could be a factor contributing to overeating and subsequent obesity.\n Only one tool, the Yale Food Addiction Scale (YFAS) has been developed to specifically assess food addiction.\n This review aimed to determine the prevalence of food addiction diagnosis and symptom scores, as assessed by the YFAS.\n Published studies to July 2014 were included if they reported the YFAS diagnosis or symptom score and were published in the English language.\n Twenty-five studies were identified including a total of 196,211 predominantly female, overweight/obese participants (60%).\n Using meta-analysis, the weighted mean prevalence of YFAS food addiction diagnosis was 19.9%.\n Food addiction (FA) diagnosis was found to be higher in adults aged &gt;35 years, females, and overweight/obese participants.\n Additionally, YFAS diagnosis and symptom score was higher in clinical samples compared to non-clinical counterparts.\n YFAS outcomes were related to a range of other eating behavior measures and anthropometrics.\n Further research is required to explore YFAS outcomes across a broader spectrum of ages, other types of eating disorders and in conjunction with weight loss interventions to confirm the efficacy of the tool to assess for the presence of FA.\n","id":"PMC4210934","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Kirrilly Approach Bias toward Addictive Substances","abstract":"Human behavior can be paradoxical, in that actions can be initiated that are seemingly incongruent with an individual’s explicit desires.\n This is most commonly observed in drug addiction, where maladaptive behavior (i.\ne.\n, drug seeking) appears to be compulsive, continuing at great personal cost.\n Approach biases toward addictive substances have been correlated with actual drug-use in a number of studies, suggesting that this measure can, in some cases, index everyday maladaptive tendencies.\n At present it is unclear whether this bias to drug cues is a Pavlovian conditioned approach response, a habitual response, the result of a Pavlovian-instrumental transfer process, or a goal-directed action in the sense that expectancy of the rewarding effects of drugs controls approach.\n We consider this question by combining the theoretical framework of associative learning with the available evidence from approach bias research.\n Although research investigating the relative contributions of these mechanisms to the approach bias is to date relatively limited, we review existing studies and also outline avenues for future Cannabis Users and Controls","abstract":"Cognitive biases, including implicit memory associations are thought to play an important role in the development of addictive behaviors.\n The aim of the present study was to investigate implicit affective memory associations in heavy cannabis users.\n Implicit positive-arousal, sedation, and negative associations toward cannabis were measured with three Single Category Implicit Association Tests (SC-IAT’s) and compared between 59 heavy cannabis users and 89 controls.\n Moreover, we investigated the relationship between these implicit affective associations and explicit expectancies, subjective craving, cannabis use, and cannabis related problems.\n Results show that heavy cannabis users had stronger implicit positive-arousal associations but weaker implicit negative associations toward cannabis compared to controls.\n Moreover, heavy cannabis users had stronger sedation but weaker negative explicit expectancies toward cannabis compared to controls.\n Within heavy cannabis users, more cannabis use was associated with stronger implicit negative associations whereas more cannabis use related problems was associated with stronger explicit negative expectancies, decreasing the overall difference on negative associations between cannabis users and controls.\n No other associations were observed between implicit associations, explicit expectancies, measures of cannabis use, cannabis use related problems, or subjective craving.\n These findings indicate that, in contrast to other substances of abuse like alcohol and tobacco, the relationship between implicit associations and cannabis use appears to be weak in heavy cannabis users.\n","id":"PMC3689035","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Esther Chocolate and Its Effect on Chocolate Consumption","abstract":"Evaluative conditioning (EC) procedures can be used to form and change attitudes toward a wide variety of objects.\n The current study examined the effects of a negative EC procedure on attitudes toward chocolate, and whether it influenced chocolate evaluation and consumption.\n Participants were randomly assigned to the experimental condition in which chocolate images were paired with negative stimuli, or the control condition in which chocolate images were randomly paired with positive stimuli (50%) and negative stimuli (50%).\n Explicit and implicit attitudes toward chocolate images were collected.\n During an ostensible taste test, chocolate evaluation and consumption were assessed.\n Results revealed that compared to participants in the control condition, participants in the experimental condition showed more negative explicit and implicit attitudes toward chocolate images and evaluated chocolate more negatively during the taste test.\n However, chocolate consumption did not differ between experimental and control conditions.\n These findings suggest that pairing chocolate with negative stimuli can influence attitudes toward chocolate, though behavioral effects are absent.\n Intervention applications of EC provide avenues for future research and practices.\n","id":"PMC5581832","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Yan","surname":"Wang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Guosen","surname":"Wang","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Dingyuan","surname":"Zhang","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Lei","surname":"Wang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Xianghua","surname":"Cui","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jinglei","surname":"Zhu","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Yuan","surname":"Fang","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1007/s10865-012-9490-5","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Changing consumption?","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1007/s00213-010-1872-1","date":"2010-04-16","title":"Learning to dislike alcohol: conditioning negative implicit attitudes toward alcohol and its effect on drinking behavior","abstract":"Rationale\nSince implicit attitudes toward alcohol play an important role in drinking behavior, a possible way to obtain a behavioral change is changing these implicit attitudes.\n\n\nObjectives\nThis study examined whether a change in implicit attitudes and in drinking behavior can be achieved via evaluative conditioning.\n\n\nMethods\nParticipants were randomly assigned to an experimental condition and a control condition.\n\n In the experimental condition, participants were subjected to an evaluative conditioning procedure that consistently pairs alcohol-related cues with negative stimuli.\n\n In the control condition, alcohol-related cues were consistently paired with neutral stimuli during the evaluative conditioning phase.\n\n Implicit attitudes, explicit attitudes, and drinking behavior were measured before and after the evaluative conditioning phase.\n\n\nResults\nFollowing the evaluative conditioning procedure, participants in the experimental condition showed stronger negative implicit attitudes toward alcohol and consumed less alcohol compared to participants in the control condition.\n\n However, this effect was only found when the evaluative conditioning task paired alcohol-related cues with general negative pictures, but not when using pictures of frowning faces.\n\n\nConclusions\nThese results demonstrate that evaluative conditioning can effectively change implicit attitudes toward alcohol and also suggest that this procedure can be used to change drinking behavior.\n\n Hence, evaluative conditioning may be a useful new intervention tool to combat alcohol misuse.\n\n\n","id":"PMC2885295","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Katrijn","surname":"Houben","email":"K.Houben@maastrichtuniversity.nl","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Remco lean and overweight/obese adults: a moderated-mediation model","abstract":"Background/Objectives:\nThe relationship between response inhibition and obesity is currently unclear.\n\n This may be because of inconsistencies in methodology, design limitations and the use of narrow samples.\n\n In addition, dietary restraint has not been considered, yet restraint has been reported to moderate performance on behavioural tasks of response inhibition.\n\n The aim of this study was to investigate performance on both a food-based and a neutral stimuli go/no-go task, which addresses current design limitations, in lean and overweight/obese adults.\n\n The moderating role of dietary restraint in the relationship between body composition, response inhibition and snack intake was also measured.\n\n\nSubjects/Methods:\nLean and overweight/obese, males and females (N=116) completed both a food-based and neutral category control go/no-go task, in a fully counterbalanced repeated-measures design.\n\n A bogus taste-test was then completed, followed by a self-report measure of dietary restraint.\n\n\nResults:\nPROCESS moderated-mediation analysis showed that overweight/obese, compared with lean, participants made more errors on the food-based (but not the neutral) go/no-go task, but only when they were low in dietary restraint.\n\n Performance on the food-based go/no-go task predicted snack intake across the sample.\n\n Increased intake in the overweight, low restrainers was fully mediated by increased errors on the food-based (but not the neutral) go/no-go task.\n\n\nConclusions:\nDistinguishing between high and low restrained eaters in the overweight/obese population is crucial in future obesity research incorporating food-based go/no-go tasks.\n\n Poor response inhibition to food cues predicts overeating across weight groups, suggesting weight loss interventions and obesity prevention programmes should target behavioural inhibition training in such (3) ICT (repeatedly inhibiting behaviour in response to alcohol cues); or (4) sham (control) ICT.\n\n Changes in reaction times and automatic evaluations of alcohol cues were assessed before and after training using assessment versions of tasks used in training and the implicit association test (IAT), respectively.\n\n Finally, participants completed a bogus taste test as a measure of ad libitum alcohol consumption.\n\n\nResults\nid='Par4'>Compared to sham conditions, CAT and ICT both led to reduced alcohol consumption although there was no difference between the two.\n\n Neither intervention affected performance on the IAT, and changes in reaction time did not suggest the formation of robust alcohol avoidance (CAT) or alcohol inhibition (ICT) associations after training.\n\n\nConclusions\nid='Par5'>CAT and ICT yielded equivalent reductions in alcohol consumption in the laboratory.\n\n However, these behavioural effects were not accompanied by devaluation of stimuli or the formation of alcohol avoidance or alcohol inhibition associations.\n\n\nElectronic supplementary material\nThe online version of this article (doi:10.1007/s00213-017-4639-0) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5537323","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Lisa C. Long-Lasting?","abstract":"A recent study has shown that short-term training in response inhibition can make people more cautious for up to two hours when making decisions.\n However, the longevity of such training effects is unclear.\n In this study we tested whether training in the stop-signal paradigm reduces risky gambling when the training and gambling task are separated by 24 hours.\n Two independent experiments revealed that the aftereffects of stop-signal training are negligible after 24 hours.\n This was supported by Bayes factors that provided strong support for the null hypothesis.\n These findings indicate the need to better optimise the parameters of inhibition training to achieve clinical efficacy, potentially by strengthening automatic associations between stimulus specificity and appropriate training protocols","abstract":"Training individuals to inhibit their responses towards unhealthy foods has been shown to reduce food intake relative to a control group.\n Here we aimed to further explore these effects by investigating the role of stimulus devaluation, training protocol, and choice of control group.\n Restrained eaters received either inhibition or control training using a modified version of either the stop-signal or go/no-go task.\n Following training we measured implicit attitudes towards food (Study 1) and food consumption (Studies 1 and 2).\n In Study 1 we used a modified stop-signal training task with increased demands on top-down control (using a tracking procedure and feedback to maintain competition between the stop and go processes).\n With this task, we found no evidence for an effect of training on implicit attitudes or food consumption, with Bayesian inferential analyses revealing substantial evidence for the null hypothesis.\n In Study 2 we removed the feedback in the stop-signal training to increase the rate of successful inhibition and revealed a significant effect of both stop-signal and go/no-go training on food intake (compared to double-response and go training, respectively) with a greater difference in consumption in the go/no-go task, compared with the stop-signal task.\n However, results from an additional passive control group suggest that training effects could be partly caused by increased consumption in the go control group whereas evidence for reduced consumption in the inhibition groups was inconclusive.\n Our findings therefore support evidence that inhibition training tasks with higher rates of inhibition accuracy are more effective, but prompt caution for interpreting the efficacy of laboratory-based inhibition training as an intervention for behaviour change.\n","id":"PMC5240656","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Rachel decrease choices for palatable foods through decreased food evaluation","abstract":"The present study explores whether presenting specific palatable foods in close temporal proximity of stop signals in a go/no-go task decreases subsequent evaluations of such foods among participants with a relatively high appetite.\n Furthermore, we tested whether any decreased evaluations could mediate subsequent food choice.\n Participants first received a go/no-go task in which palatable foods were consistently linked to go cues or no-go cues within participants.\n Next, evaluation of the palatable foods was measured as well as food choice.\n Replicating previous work, results show that among participants with a relatively high appetite palatable foods associated with no-go cues are less often chosen as snacks compared to when these foods are associated with go cues, whereas this manipulation did not affect participants with a relatively low appetite.\n Moreover, this effect was completely mediated by decreased evaluation of the palatable foods that had been associated with the no-go cues, whereas evaluation of the foods associated with go cues did not mediate this effect.\n Results further showed that the devaluation effect of foods associated with no-go cues was independent of the amount of pairings (4 vs.\n 12 vs.\n 24) with the no-go cues.\n The current findings suggest that decreased food evaluation is a mechanism that explains effects of stop signals on food and reduced energy intake","abstract":"The majority of adults in the UK and US are overweight or obese due to multiple factors including excess energy intake.\n Training people to inhibit simple motor responses (key presses) to high-energy density food pictures reduces intake in laboratory studies.\n We examined whether online response inhibition training reduced real-world food consumption and weight in a community sample of adults who were predominantly overweight or obese (N = 83).\n Participants were allocated in a randomised, double-blind design to receive four 10-min sessions of either active or control go/no-go training in which either high-energy density snack foods (active) or non-food stimuli (control) were associated with no-go signals.\n Participants' weight, energy intake (calculated from 24-h food diaries), daily snacking frequency and subjective food evaluations were measured for one week pre- and post-intervention.\n Participants also provided self-reported weight and monthly snacking frequency at pre-intervention screening, and one month and six months after completing the study.\n Participants in the active relative to control condition showed significant weight loss, reductions in daily energy intake and a reduction in rated liking of high-energy density (no-go) foods from the pre-to post-intervention week.\n There were no changes in self-reported daily snacking frequency.\n At longer-term follow-up, the active group showed significant reductions in self-reported weight at six months, whilst both groups reported significantly less snacking at one- and six-months.\n Excellent rates of adherence (97%) and positive feedback about the training suggest that this intervention is acceptable and has the potential to improve public health by reducing energy intake and overweight.\n","id":"PMC4596151","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Natalia induced by verbal suggestions might optimize the effectiveness of these interventions, as shown in placebo research.\n The present study investigated the effectiveness of a gamified approach-avoidance training on food-related outcomes and whether verbal suggestions could strengthen those effects.\n A total of 120 participants were randomly assigned to 1 of 4 conditions: serious gaming only, verbal suggestions only, serious gaming combined with verbal suggestions, or a gaming control condition.\n Virtual food preference and food choice were assessed with a food choice task, with pairs differing in healthiness or in healthiness and attractiveness.\n Implicit food preference was assessed with an Implicit Association Test and food intake with a bogus taste test.\n Participants in both serious gaming conditions made healthier food choices for pairs differing in healthiness and attractiveness and had healthier implicit food preferences compared to gaming control.\n No effects were found on food intake.\n These findings provide the first preliminary support for the effects of a gamified approach-avoidance training on virtual food choice and implicit food preference.\n Future studies found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.3389/fpsyt.2016.00133","date":"2016-07-19","title":"Bilateral Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation of the Prefrontal Cortex Reduces Cocaine Intake: A Pilot Study","abstract":"Background\nChronic cocaine consumption is associated with a decrease in mesolimbic dopamine transmission that maintains drug intake.\n\n transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) is gaining reliability, a useful therapeutic tool in drug addiction, since it can modulate cortico-limbic activity resulting in reduction of drug craving.\n\n\nAims\nIn the present study, we investigated the therapeutic effect of bilateral TMS of prefrontal cortex (PFC) in reducing cocaine intake, in a sample of treatment-seeking patients with current cocaine use disorder (DSM-V).\n\n\nMethods\nTen cocaine addicts (DSM-V) were randomly assigned to the active or sham stimulation protocol in a double-blind experimental design.\n\n Twelve repetitive TMS (rTMS) sessions were administered three times a week for 4 weeks at 100% of motor threshold, over bilateral PFC.\n\n Cocaine intake (ng/mg) was assessed by hair analysis at baseline (before treatment, T0), after 1 month (end of treatment, T1), 3 (T2), and 6 (T3) months later.\n\n All subjects received psychological support weekly.\n\n\nResults\nThe two-way ANOVA for repeated measures did not show a significant effect of the interaction between time and treatment (F4,32?=?0.35; p?=?0.87).\n\n Despite that result indicated no difference in the effect of the two conditions (active vs.\n\n sham) along time, a decreasing trend in cocaine consumption in active TMS group (F3,23?=?3.42; p?=?0.04) vs.\n\n sham (F3,15?=?1.88; p?=?0.20) was observed when we performed exploratory analysis with time as factor.\n\n Indeed, Post hoc comparisons showed a significant reduction in the amount of cocaine detected from the onset to 3?months later (T0–T2; p?=?0.02) and to the end of treatment (T0–T3; p?=?0.01) in addicts from the active group.\n\n\nConclusion\nBilateral rTMS of PFC at 10?Hz did not show a significant effect on cocaine intake compared to sham.\n\n However, a long-term reduction on cocaine intake in active TMS-treated patients was observed when we considered the time as factor.\n\n Further studies are required to confirm these encouraging but preliminary findings, in order to consolidate rTMS as a valid tool to treat cocaine addiction.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4976094","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Corinna","surname":"Bolloni","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Riccardo","surname":"Panella","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Mariano","surname":"Pedetti","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Anna brain","abstract":"Background\n'The feeling of being there' is one possible way to describe the phenomenon of feeling present in a virtual environment and to act as if this environment is real.\n\n control of impulsive behavior.\n\n\nMethods\nIn our experiment we applied transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) to the right dlPFC in order to modulate the experience of presence while watching a virtual roller coaster ride.\n\n During the ride we also registered electro-dermal activity.\n\n Subjects also performed a test measuring impulsiveness and answered a questionnaire about their presence feeling while they were exposed to the virtual roller coaster scenario.\n\n\nResults\nApplication of cathodal tDCS to the right dlPFC while subjects were exposed to a virtual roller coaster scenario modulates the electrodermal response to the virtual reality stimulus.\n\n In addition, measures reflecting impulsiveness were also modulated by application of cathodal tDCS to the right dlPFC.\n\n\nConclusion\nModulating the activation with the right dlPFC results in substantial changes in responses of the vegetative nervous system and changed impulsiveness.\n\n The effects can signals","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.3389/fpsyt.2011.00064","date":"2011-11-02","title":"The Dopamine Hypothesis of Drug Addiction and Its Potential Therapeutic Value","abstract":"Dopamine (DA) transmission is deeply affected by drugs of abuse, and alterations in DA function are involved in the various phases of drug addiction and potentially exploitable therapeutically.\n In particular, basic studies have documented a reduction in the electrophysiological activity of DA neurons in alcohol, opiate, cannabinoid, and other drug-dependent rats.\n Further, DA release in the Nucleus accumbens (Nacc) is decreased in virtually all drug-dependent rodents.\n In parallel, these studies are supported by increments in intracranial self stimulation (ICSS) thresholds during withdrawal from alcohol, nicotine, opiates, and other drugs of abuse, thereby suggesting a hypofunction of the neural substrate of ICSS.\n Accordingly, morphological evaluations fed into realistic computational analysis of the medium spiny neuron of the Nacc, post-synaptic counterpart of DA terminals, show profound changes in structure and function of the entire mesolimbic system.\n In line with these findings, human imaging studies have shown a reduction of dopamine receptors accompanied by a lesser release of endogenous DA in the ventral striatum of cocaine, heroin, and alcohol-dependent subjects, thereby offering visual proof of the “dopamine-impoverished” addicted human brain.\n The lasting reduction in physiological activity of the DA system leads to the idea that an increment in its activity, to restore pre-drug levels, may yield significant clinical improvements (reduction of craving, relapse, and drug-seeking/taking).\n In theory, it may be achieved pharmacologically and/or with novel interventions such as transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS).\n Its anatomo-physiological rationale as a possible therapeutic aid in alcoholics and other addicts will be described and proposed as a theoretical framework to be subjected to experimental testing in human addicts.\n","id":"PMC3225760","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Marco","surname":"Diana","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1523/JNEUROSCI.21-15-j0003.2001","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Repetitive Modulation with Bilateral tDCS in Patients with Crack-Cocaine Dependence","abstract":"Background:\nTranscranial direct current stimulation over the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex has been shown to be clinically useful in the treatment of drug addiction.\n\n\nMethods:\nWe conducted a double-blind randomized clinical trial aiming to assess the effects of bilateral dorsolateral prefrontal cortex transcranial direct current stimulation (left cathodal/right anodal) on crack-cocaine addiction.\n\n We defined craving as the primary outcome, and other clinical measurements, including depressive and anxiety symtoms, and quality of life, as secondary outcomes.\n\n Seventeen male crack-cocaine users (mean age 30.4±9.8 SD) were randomized to receive 5 sessions of active transcranial direct current stimulation (2 mA, 35cm2, for 20 minutes), every other day, and 19 males (mean age 30.3±8.4 SD) to receive sham-transcranial direct current stimulation (placebo) as control group.\n\n\nResults:\nCraving scores were significantly reduced in the transcranial direct current stimulation group after treatment when compared with sham-transcranial direct current stimulation (P=.\n\n028) and baseline values (P=.\n\n003), and decreased linearly over 4 weeks (before, during, and after treatment) in the transcranial direct current stimulation group only (P=.\n\n047).\n\n Changes of anxiety scores towards increase in the sham-transcranial direct current stimulation and decrease in the transcranial direct current stimulation group (P=.\n\n03), and of the overall perception of quality of life (P=.\n\n031) and of health (P=.\n\n048) towards decrease in the sham-transcranial direct current stimulation group and increase in the transcranial direct current stimulation group differed significantly between groups.\n\n\nConclusions:\nRepetitive bilateral transcranial direct current stimulation over the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex reduced craving for crack-cocaine use, decreased anxiety, and improved quality of life.\n\n We hypothesize that transcranial direct current stimulation effects may be associated with increased prefrontal processing and regulation of craving behavior.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4675977","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Edson prefrontal cortex (PFC) would inhibit food cravings in healthy women who endorsed frequent food cravings.\n Ten participants viewed images of food and completed ratings for food cravings before and after receiving either real or sham rTMS over the left PFC (10 Hz, 100% resting motor threshold, 10?s-on, 20?s-off for 15?min; 3000 pulses).\n Sham-TMS was matched with real TMS with respect to perceived painfulness of the stimulation.\n Each participant received both real and sham rTMS in random order and were blind to the condition in a within-subject cross-over design.\n With an improved sham control condition, prefrontal rTMS inhibited food cravings no better than sham rTMS.\n The mild pain from the real and sham rTMS may distract or inhibit food craving, and the decreased craving may not be caused by the effect of rTMS itself.\n Further studies are needed to elucidate whether rTMS has any true effects on food craving and whether painful stimuli inhibit food or other found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1007/s10484-013-9218-5","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Neurofeedback Training for Opiate Addiction: Improvement of Mental Health and Craving","abstract":"Psychological improvements in patients with substance use disorders have been reported after neurofeedback treatment.\n However, neurofeedback has not been commonly accepted as a treatment for substance dependence.\n This study was carried out to examine the effectiveness of this therapeutic method for opiate dependence disorder.\n The specific aim was to investigate whether treatment leads to any changes in mental health and substance craving.\n In this experimental study with a pre-post test design, 20 opiate dependent patients undergoing Methadone or Buprenorphine maintenance treatment were examined and matched and randomized into two groups.\n While both experimental and control groups received their usual maintenance treatment, the experimental group received 30 sessions of neurofeedback treatment in addition.\n The neurofeedback treatment consisted of sensory motor rhythm training on Cz, followed by an alpha-theta protocol on Pz.\n Data from the general health questionnaire and a heroin craving questionnaire were collected before and after treatment.\n Multivariate analysis of covariance showed that the experimental group achieved improvement in somatic symptoms, depression, and total score in general mental health; and in anticipation of positive outcome, desire to use opioid, and relief from withdrawal of craving in comparison with the control group.\n The study supports the effectiveness of neurofeedback training as a therapeutic method in opiate dependence disorder, in supplement to Adiposity","abstract":"The anterior insular cortex (AIC) is involved in emotional processes and gustatory functions which can be examined by imaging techniques.\n Such imaging studies showed increased activation in the insula in response to food stimuli as well as a differential activation in lean and obese people.\n Additionally, studies investigating lean subjects established the voluntary regulation of the insula by a real-time functional magnetic resonance imaging-brain computer interface (rtfMRI-BCI) approach.\n In this exploratory study, 11 lean and 10 obese healthy, male participants were investigated in a rtfMRI-BCI protocol.\n During the training sessions, all obese participants were able to regulate the activity of the AIC voluntarily, while four lean participants were not able to regulate at all.\n In successful regulators, functional connectivity during regulation vs.\n relaxation between the AIC and all other regions of the brain was determined by a seed voxel approach.\n Lean in comparison to obese regulators showed stronger connectivity in cingular and temporal cortices during regulation.\n We conclude, that obese people possess an improved capacity
