multi-sensor physical activity monitors","abstract":"Wearable physical activity monitors are growing in popularity and provide the opportunity for large numbers of the public to self-monitor physical activity behaviours.\n The latest generation of these devices feature multiple sensors, ostensibly similar or even superior to advanced research instruments.\n However, little is known about the accuracy of their energy expenditure estimates.\n Here, we assessed their performance against criterion measurements in both controlled laboratory conditions (simulated activities of daily living and structured exercise) and over a 24 hour period in free-living conditions.\n Thirty men (n = 15) and women (n = 15) wore three multi-sensor consumer monitors (Microsoft Band, Apple Watch and Fitbit Charge HR), an accelerometry-only device as a comparison (Jawbone UP24) and validated research-grade multi-sensor devices (BodyMedia Core and individually calibrated Actiheart™).\n During discrete laboratory activities when compared against indirect calorimetry, the Apple Watch performed similarly to criterion measures.\n The Fitbit Charge HR was less consistent at measurement of discrete activities, but produced similar free-living estimates to the Apple Watch.\n Both these devices underestimated free-living energy expenditure (-394 kcal/d and -405 kcal/d, respectively; P&lt;0.01).\n The multi-sensor Microsoft Band and accelerometry-only Jawbone UP24 devices underestimated most laboratory activities and substantially underestimated free-living expenditure (-1128 kcal/d and -998 kcal/d, respectively; P&lt;0.01).\n None of the consumer devices were deemed equivalent to the reference method for daily energy expenditure.\n For all devices, there was a tendency for negative bias with greater daily energy expenditure.\n No consumer monitors performed as well as the research-grade devices although in some (but not all) cases, estimates were close to criterion measurements.\n Thus, whilst industry-led innovation has improved the accuracy of consumer monitors, these devices are not yet equivalent to the best research-grade devices or indeed equivalent to each other.\n We propose independent quality standards and/or accuracy ratings for consumer devices are required.\n","id":"PMC5325221","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Enhad Analysis","abstract":"Background\nWearable activity trackers are promising as interventions that offer guidance and support for increasing physical activity and health-focused tracking.\n\n Most adults do not meet their recommended daily activity guidelines, and wearable fitness trackers are increasingly cited as having great potential to improve the physical activity levels of adults.\n\n\nObjective\nThe objective of this study was to use the Coventry, Aberdeen, and London-Refined (CALO-RE) taxonomy to examine if the design of wearable activity trackers incorporates behavior change techniques (BCTs).\n\n A secondary objective was to critically analyze whether the BCTs present relate to known drivers of behavior change, such as self-efficacy, with the intention of extending applicability to older adults in addition to the overall population.\n\n\nMethods\nWearing each device for a period of 1 week, two independent raters used CALO-RE taxonomy to code the BCTs of the seven wearable activity trackers available in Canada as of March 2014. These included Fitbit Flex, Misfit Shine, Withings Pulse, Jawbone UP24, Spark Activity Tracker by SparkPeople, Nike+ FuelBand SE, and Polar Loop.\n\n We calculated interrater reliability using Cohen's kappa.\n\n\nResults\nThe average number of BCTs identified was 16.3/40. Withings Pulse had the highest number of BCTs and Misfit Shine had the lowest.\n\n Most techniques centered around self-monitoring and self-regulation, all of which have been associated with improved physical activity in older adults.\n\n Techniques related to planning and providing instructions were scarce.\n\n\nConclusions\nOverall, wearable activity trackers contain several BCTs that have been shown to increase physical activity in older adults.\n\n Although more research and development must be done to fully understand the potential of wearables as health interventions, the current wearable trackers offer significant potential with regard to BCTs relevant to uptake by all populations, including older adults.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4917727","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Gunther","surname":"Eysenbach","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Elizabeth","surname":"Lyons","email":"NULL","contributions":"4"},{"firstname":"Elizabeth","surname":"Lyons","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Andre","surname":"Müller","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Kathryn","surname":"Mercer","email":"NULL","contributions":"4"},{"firstname":"Kathryn","surname":"Mercer","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Melissa","surname":"Li","email":"NULL","contributions":"4"},{"firstname":"Melissa","surname":"Li","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Lora","surname":"Giangregorio","email":"NULL","contributions":"4"},{"firstname":"Lora","surname":"Giangregorio","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Catherine","surname":"Burns","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Catherine","surname":"Burns","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Kelly","surname":"Grindrod","email":"kelly.grindrod@uwaterloo.ca","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Kelly","surname":"Grindrod","email":"kelly.grindrod@uwaterloo.ca","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.2196/mhealth.7647","date":"2017-05-11","title":"A Bit of Fit: Minimalist Intervention in Adolescents Based on a Physical Activity Tracker","abstract":"Background\nOnly 5% of Canadian youth meet the recommended 60 minutes of moderate to vigorous physical activity (MVPA) per day, with leisure time being increasingly allocated to technology usage.\n\n Direct-to-consumer mHealth devices that promote physical activity, such as wrist-worn physical activity trackers, have features with potential appeal to youth.\n\n\nObjective\nThe primary purpose of this study was to determine whether a minimalist physical activity tracker-based intervention would lead to an increase in physical activity in young adolescents.\n\n A secondary aim of this study was to assess change in physical activity across a 7-week intervention, as measured by the tracker.\n\n\nMethods\nUsing a quasi-experimental crossover design, two groups of 23 young adolescents (aged 13-14 years) were randomly assigned to immediate intervention or delayed intervention.\n\n in physical activity over the course of the study period, though it was not related to overall physical activity tracker use.\n\n An intervention response did, however, occur in a subset of being in the action and maintenance stages of behavior change in relation to participation in physical activity.\n\n Participants in the precontemplation, contemplation, and preparation stages of behavior change had no change in their level of MVPA (P=.\n\n81).\n\n\nConclusions\nThese results suggest that physical activity trackers may elicit improved physical activity related behavior in young adolescents demonstrating a readiness to be active.\n\n Future studies should seek to investigate if integrating physical activity trackers as part of more intensive interventions leads to Community-Based Physical Activity Counselling Program for People With Knee Osteoarthritis: Feasibility and Preliminary Efficacy of the Track-OA Study","abstract":"Background\nPhysical activity can improve health outcomes in people with knee osteoarthritis (OA); however, participation in physical activity is very low in this population.\n\n\nObjective\nThe objective of our study was to assess the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of the use of wearables (Fitbit Flex) and telephone counselling by a physical therapist (PT) for improving physical activity in people with a physician-confirmed diagnosis of knee OA, or who have passed 2 validated criteria for early OA.\n\n \nMethods\nWe conducted a community-based feasibility randomized controlled trial.\n\n The immediate group (n=17) received a brief education session by a physical therapist, a Fitbit Flex activity tracker, and a weekly telephone call for activity counselling with the physical therapist.\n\n The delayed group (n=17) received the same intervention 1 month later.\n\n All participants were assessed at baseline (T0), and the end of 1 month (T1) and 2 months (T2).\n\n Outcomes were (1) mean moderate to vigorous physical activity time, (2) mean time spent on sedentary behavior, (3) Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS), and (4) Partners in Health Scale.\n\n Feasibility data were summarized with descriptive statistics.\n\n We used analysis of covariance to evaluate the effect of the group type on the outcome measures at T1 and T2, after adjusting for blocking and T0. We assessed planned contrasts of changes in outcome measures over measurement periods.\n\n\nResults\nWe identified 46 eligible individuals; of those, 34 (74%) enrolled and no one dropped out.\n\n All but 1 participant adhered to the intervention protocol.\n\n We found a significant effect, with the immediate intervention group having improved in the moderate to vigorous physical activity time and in the Partners in Health Scale at T0 to T1 compared with the delayed intervention group.\n\n The planned contrast of the immediate intervention group at T0 to T1 versus the delayed group at T1 to T2 showed a significant effect in the sedentary time and the KOOS symptoms subscale, favoring the delayed group.\n\n\nConclusions\nThis study demonstrated the feasibility of a behavioral intervention, supported by the use of a wearable device, to promote physical activity among people with knee OA.\n\n\nTrial Registration\nClinicalTrials.\n\ngov NCT02313506; mean age, 22.8 years) wore the Fitbit Charge HR and the Actiwatch 2 on the same wrist; a sleep log was recorded over a 14-day period.\n\n We compared the sleep variables and circadian rest-activity rhythm measures with Wilcoxon signed-rank tests and Spearman's correlations.\n\n\nResults\nThe periods and acrophases of the circadian rest-activity rhythms and the sleep start times did not differ and correlated significantly between the Fitbit Charge HR and the Actiwatch 2. The Fitbit Charge HR tended to overestimate the sleep durations compared with the Actiwatch 2. However, the sleep durations showed high correlation between the two devices for all days.\n\n\nConclusion\nWe found that the Fitbit Charge HR showed high accuracy in sleep evaluation and circadian rest-activity rhythm measurement when compared with actigraphy for healthy young adults.\n\n The results suggest that the Fitbit Charge HR could be applicable on medical research as an alternative tool to actigraphy for sleep evaluation and measurement of the circadian rest-activity rhythm.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5355016","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Hyun-Ah","surname":"Lee","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Heon-Jeong","surname":"Lee","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Joung-Ho","surname":"Moon","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Taek","surname":"Lee","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Min-Gwan","surname":"Kim","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Hoh","surname":"In","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Chul-Hyun","surname":"Cho","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Leen","surname":"Kim","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0172535","date":"2017-02-06","title":"Comparison of wrist-worn Fitbit Flex and waist-worn ActiGraph for measuring steps in free-living adults","abstract":"Introduction\nAccelerometers are commonly used to assess physical activity.\n\n Consumer activity trackers have become increasingly popular today, such as the Fitbit.\n\n This study aimed to compare the average number of steps per day using the wrist-worn Fitbit Flex and waist-worn ActiGraph (wGT3X-BT) in free-living conditions.\n\n\nMethods\n104 adult participants (n = 35 males; n = 69 females) were asked to wear a Fitbit Flex and an ActiGraph concurrently for 7 days.\n\n Daily step counts were used to classify inactive (&lt;10,000 steps) and active (?10,000 steps) days, which is one of the commonly used physical activity guidelines to maintain health.\n\n Proportion of agreement between physical activity categorizations from ActiGraph and Fitbit Flex was assessed.\n\n Statistical analyses included Spearman’s rho, intraclass correlation (ICC), median absolute percentage error (MAPE), Kappa statistics, and Bland-Altman plots.\n\n Analyses were performed among all participants, by each step-defined daily physical activity category and gender.\n\n\nResults\nThe median average steps/day recorded by Fitbit Flex and ActiGraph were 10193 and 8812, respectively.\n\n Strong positive correlations and agreement were found for all participants, both genders, as well as daily physical activity categories (Spearman's rho: 0.76–0.91; ICC: 0.73–0.87).\n\n The MAPE was: 15.5% (95% confidence interval [CI]: 5.8–28.1%) for overall steps, 16.9% (6.8–30.3%) vs.\n\n 15.1% (4.5–27.3%) in males and females, and 20.4% (8.7–35.9%) vs.\n\n 9.6% (1.0–18.4%) during inactive days and active days.\n\n Bland-Altman plot indicated a median overestimation of 1300 steps/day by the Fitbit Flex in all participants.\n\n Fitbit Flex and ActiGraph respectively classified 51.5% and 37.5% of the days as active (Kappa: 0.66).\n\n\nConclusions\nThere were high correlations and agreement in steps between Fitbit Flex and ActiGraph.\n\n However, findings suggested discrepancies in steps between devices.\n\n This imposed a challenge that needs to be considered when using Fibit Flex in research and health promotion programs.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5325470","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Anne H. Self-Monitoring Heart Rate and Physical Activity Wearable Devices","abstract":"Background\nPhysical activity tracking wearable devices have emerged as an increasingly popular method for consumers to assess their daily activity and calories expended.\n\n However, whether these wearable devices are valid at different levels of exercise intensity is unknown.\n\n\nObjective\nThe objective of this study was to examine heart rate (HR) and energy expenditure (EE) validity of 3 popular wrist-worn activity monitors at different exercise intensities.\n\n\nMethods\nA total of 62 participants (females: 58%, 36/62; nonwhite: 47% [13/62 Hispanic, 8/62 Asian, 7/62 black/ African American, 1/62 other]) wore the Apple Watch, Fitbit Charge HR, and Garmin Forerunner 225. Validity was assessed using 2 criterion devices: HR chest strap and a metabolic cart.\n\n Participants completed a 10-minute seated baseline assessment; separate 4-minute stages of light-, moderate-, and vigorous-intensity treadmill exercises; and a 10-minute seated recovery period.\n\n Data from devices were compared with each criterion via two-way repeated-measures analysis of variance and Bland-Altman analysis.\n\n Differences are expressed in mean absolute percentage error (MAPE).\n\n\nResults\nFor the Apple Watch, HR MAPE was between 1.14% and 6.70%.\n\n HR was not significantly different at the start (P=.\n\n78), during baseline (P=.\n\n76), or vigorous intensity (P=.\n\n84); lower HR readings were measured during light intensity (P=.\n\n03), moderate intensity (P=.\n\n001), and recovery (P=.\n\n004).\n\n EE MAPE was between 14.07% and 210.84%.\n\n The device measured higher EE at all stages (P&lt;.\n\n01).\n\n For the Fitbit device, the HR MAPE was between 2.38% and 16.99%.\n\n HR was not significantly different at the start (P=.\n\n67) or during moderate intensity (P=.\n\n34); lower HR readings were measured during baseline, vigorous intensity, and recovery (P&lt;.\n\n001) and higher HR during light intensity (P&lt;.\n\n001).\n\n EE MAPE was between 16.85% and 84.98%.\n\n The device measured higher EE at baseline (P=.\n\n003), light intensity (P&lt;.\n\n001), and moderate intensity (P=.\n\n001).\n\n EE was not significantly different at vigorous (P=.\n\n70) or recovery (P=.\n\n10).\n\n For Garmin Forerunner 225, HR MAPE was between 7.87% and 24.38%.\n\n HR was not significantly different at vigorous intensity (P=.\n\n35).\n\n The device measured higher HR readings at start, baseline, light intensity, moderate intensity (P&lt;.\n\n001), and recovery (P=.\n\n04).\n\n EE MAPE was between 30.77% and 155.05%.\n\n The device measured higher EE at all stages (P&lt;.\n\n001).\n\n\nConclusions\nThis study provides one of the first validation assessments for the Fitbit Charge HR, Apple Watch, and Garmin Forerunner 225. An advantage and novel approach of the study is the examination of HR and EE at specific physical activity intensities.\n\n Establishing validity of wearable devices is of particular interest as these devices are being used in weight loss interventions and could impact findings.\n\n Future research should investigate why differences between exercise intensities and the devices Are they accurate enough?","abstract":"Background\nHeart rate (HR) monitors are valuable devices for fitness-orientated individuals.\n\n There has been a vast influx of optical sensing blood flow monitors claiming to provide accurate HR during physical activities.\n\n These monitors are worn on the arm and wrist to detect HR with photoplethysmography (PPG) techniques.\n\n Little is known about the validity of these wearable activity trackers.\n\n\nAim\nValidate the Scosche Rhythm (SR), Mio Alpha (MA), Fitbit Charge HR (FH), Basis Peak (BP), Microsoft Band (MB), and TomTom Runner Cardio (TT) wireless HR monitors.\n\n\nMethods\n50 volunteers (males: n=32, age 19–43?years; females: n=18, age 19–38?years) participated.\n\n All monitors were worn simultaneously in a randomised configuration.\n\n The Polar RS400 HR chest strap was the criterion measure.\n\n A treadmill protocol of one 30?min bout of continuous walking and running at 3.2, 4.8, 6.4, 8.0, and 9.6?km/h (5?min at each protocol speed) with HR manually recorded every minute was completed.\n\n\nResults\nFor group comparisons, the mean absolute percentage error values were: 3.3%, 3.6%, 4.0%, 4.6%, 4.8% and 6.2% for TT, BP, RH, MA, MB and FH, respectively.\n\n Pearson product-moment correlation coefficient (r) was observed: r=0.959 (TT), r=0.956 (MB), r=0.954 (BP), r=0.933 (FH), r=0.930 (RH) and r=0.929 (MA).\n\n Results from 95% equivalency testing showed monitors were found to be equivalent to those of the criterion HR (±10% equivalence zone: 98.15–119.96).\n\n\nConclusions\nThe results demonstrate that the wearable activity trackers provide an accurate measurement of HR during walking and running activities.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5117066","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Sarah E","surname":"Stahl","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Hyun-Sung","surname":"An","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Hyun-Sung","surname":"An","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Danae M","surname":"Dinkel","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"John M","surname":"Noble","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jung-Min","surname":"Lee","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.2196/mhealth.6321","date":"2017-05-11","title":"How Accurate Is Your Activity Tracker? A Comparative Study of Step Counts in Low-Intensity Physical Activities","abstract":"Background\nAs commercially available activity trackers are being utilized in clinical trials, the research community remains uncertain about reliability of the trackers, particularly in studies that involve walking aids and low-intensity activities.\n\n While these trackers have been tested for reliability during walking and running activities, there has been limited research on validating them during low-intensity activities and walking with assistive tools.\n\n\nObjective\nThe aim of this study was to (1) determine the accuracy of 3 Fitbit devices (ie, Zip, One, and Flex) at different wearing positions (ie, pants pocket, chest, and wrist) during walking at 3 different speeds, 2.5, 5, and 8 km/h, performed by healthy adults on a treadmill; (2) determine the accuracy of the mentioned trackers worn at different sites during activities of daily living; and (3) examine whether intensity of physical activity (PA) impacts the choice of optimal wearing site of the tracker.\n\n\nMethods\nWe recruited 15 healthy young adults to perform 6 PAs while wearing 3 Fitbit devices (ie, Zip, One, and Flex) on their chest, pants pocket, and wrist.\n\n The activities include walking at 2.5, 5, and 8 km/h, pushing a shopping cart, walking with aid of a walker, and eating while sitting.\n\n We compared the number of steps counted by each tracker with gold standard numbers.\n\n We performed multiple statistical analyses to compute descriptive statistics (ie, ANOVA test), intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC), mean absolute error rate, and correlation by comparing the tracker-recorded data with that of the gold standard.\n\n\nResults\nAll the 3 trackers demonstrated good-to-excellent (ICC&gt;0.75) correlation with the gold standard step counts during treadmill experiments.\n\n The correlation was poor (ICC&lt;0.60), and the error rate was significantly higher in walker experiment compared to other activities.\n\n There was no significant difference between the trackers and the gold standard in the shopping cart experiment.\n\n The wrist worn tracker, Flex, counted several steps when eating (P&lt;.\n\n01).\n\n The chest tracker was identified as the most promising site to capture steps in more intense activities, while the wrist was the optimal wearing site in less intense activities.\n\n\nConclusions\nThis feasibility study focused on 6 PAs and demonstrated that Fitbit trackers were most accurate when walking on a treadmill and least accurate during walking with a walking aid and for low-intensity activities.\n\n This may suggest excluding participants with assistive devices from studies that focus on PA interventions using commercially available trackers.\n\n This study also indicates that the wearing site of the tracker is an important factor impacting the accuracy performance.\n\n A larger scale study with a more diverse population, various activity tracker vendors, and a larger activity set are warranted to generalize our results.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5572056","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Gunther","surname":"Eysenbach","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"David","surname":"Glance","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"David","surname":"Glance","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Sjaan","surname":"Gomersall","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Charlotte","surname":"Thorup","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Parastoo","surname":"Alinia","email":"parastoo.alinia@wsu.edu","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Parastoo","surname":"Alinia","email":"parastoo.alinia@wsu.edu","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Chris","surname":"Cain","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Chris","surname":"Cain","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Ramin","surname":"Fallahzadeh","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Ramin","surname":"Fallahzadeh","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Armin","surname":"Shahrokni","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Armin","surname":"Shahrokni","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Diane","surname":"Cook","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Diane","surname":"Cook","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Hassan","surname":"Ghasemzadeh","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Hassan","surname":"Ghasemzadeh","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.3389/fneur.2017.00160","date":"2017-04-05","title":"Improved Mental Acuity Forecasting with an Individualized Quantitative Sleep Model","abstract":"Sleep impairment significantly alters human brain structure and cognitive function, but available evidence suggests that adults in developed nations are sleeping less.\n A growing body of research has sought to use sleep to forecast cognitive performance by modeling the relationship between the two, but has generally focused on vigilance rather than other cognitive constructs affected by sleep, such as reaction time, executive function, and working memory.\n Previous modeling efforts have also utilized subjective, self-reported sleep durations and were restricted to laboratory environments.\n In the current effort, we addressed these limitations by employing wearable systems and mobile applications to gather objective sleep information, assess multi-construct cognitive performance, and model/predict changes to mental acuity.\n Thirty participants were recruited for participation in the study, which lasted 1?week.\n Using the Fitbit Charge HR and a mobile version of the automated neuropsychological assessment metric called CogGauge, we gathered a series of features and utilized the unified model of performance to predict mental acuity based on sleep records.\n Our results suggest that individuals poorly rate their sleep duration, supporting the need for objective sleep metrics to model circadian changes to mental acuity.\n Participant compliance in using the wearable throughout the week and responding to the CogGauge assessments was 80%.\n Specific biases were identified in temporal metrics across mobile devices and operating systems and were excluded from the mental acuity metric development.\n Individualized prediction of mental acuity consistently outperformed group modeling.\n This effort indicates the feasibility of creating an individualized, mobile assessment and prediction of mental acuity, compatible with the majority of current mobile devices.\n","id":"PMC5403829","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Brent found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.2196/mhealth.7870","date":"2017-05-25","title":"Mobile Device Accuracy for Step Counting Across Age Groups","abstract":"Background\nOnly one in five American meets the physical activity recommendations of the Department of Health and Human Services.\n\n The proliferation of wearable devices and smartphones for physical activity tracking has led to an increasing number of interventions designed to facilitate regular physical activity, in particular to address the obesity epidemic, but also for cardiovascular disease patients, cancer survivors, and older adults.\n\n However, the inconsistent findings pertaining to the accuracy of wearable devices for step counting needs to be addressed, as well as factors known to affect gait (and thus potentially impact accuracy) such as age, body mass index (BMI), or leading arm.\n\n\nObjective\nWe aim to assess the accuracy of recent mobile devices for counting steps, across three different age groups.\n\n\nMethods\nWe recruited 60 participants in three age groups: 18-39 years, 40-64 years, and 65-84 years, who completed two separate 1000 step walks on a treadmill at a self-selected speed between 2 and 3 miles per hour.\n\n We tested two smartphones attached on each side of the waist, and five wrist-based devices worn on both wrists (2 devices on one wrist and 3 devices on the other), as well as the Actigraph wGT3X-BT, and swapped sides between each walk.\n\n All devices were swapped dominant-to-nondominant side and vice-versa between the two 1000 step walks.\n\n The number of steps was recorded with a tally counter.\n\n Age, sex, height, weight, and dominant hand were self-reported by each participant.\n\n\nResults\nAmong the 60 participants, 36 were female (60%) and 54 were right-handed (90%).\n\n Median age was 53 years (min=19, max=83), median BMI was 24.1 (min=18.4, max=39.6).\n\n There was no significant difference in left- and right-hand step counts by device.\n\n Our analyses show that the Fitbit Surge significantly undercounted steps across all age groups.\n\n Samsung Gear S2 significantly undercounted steps only for participants among the 40-64 year age group.\n\n Finally, the Nexus 6P significantly undercounted steps for the group ranging from 65-84 years.\n\n\nConclusions\nOur analysis shows that apart from the Fitbit Surge, most of the recent mobile devices we tested do not overcount or undercount steps in the 18-39-year-old age group, however some devices undercount steps in older age groups.\n\n This finding suggests that accuracy in step counting may be an issue with some popular wearable devices, and that age may be a factor in undercounting.\n\n These results are particularly important for clinical interventions using such devices and other activity trackers, in particular to balance energy requirements with energy expenditure in the context of a weight loss intervention program.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5508112","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Gunther","surname":"Eysenbach","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jianbo","surname":"Lei","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Jianbo","surname":"Lei","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Stephanie","surname":"Schoeppe","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"François","surname":"Modave","email":"modavefp@ufl.edu","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"François","surname":"Modave","email":"modavefp@ufl.edu","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yi","surname":"Guo","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yi","surname":"Guo","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jiang","surname":"Bian","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jiang","surname":"Bian","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Matthew W","surname":"Buford","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.2196/mhealth.6281","date":"2016-08-24","title":"Physical Activity Assessment Between Consumer- and Research-Grade Accelerometers: A Comparative Study in Free-Living Conditions","abstract":"Background\nWearable activity monitors such as Fitbit enable users to track various attributes of their physical activity (PA) over time and have the potential to be used in research to promote and measure PA behavior.\n\n However, the measurement accuracy of Fitbit in absolute free-living conditions is largely unknown.\n\n\nObjective\nTo examine the measurement congruence between Fitbit Flex and ActiGraph GT3X for quantifying steps, metabolic equivalent tasks (METs), and proportion of time in sedentary activity and light-, moderate-, and vigorous-intensity PA in healthy adults in free-living conditions.\n\n\nMethods\nA convenience sample of 19 participants (4 men and 15 women), aged 18-37 years, concurrently wore the Fitbit Flex (wrist) and ActiGraph GT3X (waist) for 1- or 2-week observation periods (n=3 and n=16, respectively) that included self-reported bouts of daily exercise.\n\n Data were examined for daily activity, averaged over 14 days and for minutes of reported exercise.\n\n Average day-level data included steps, METs, and proportion of time in different intensity levels.\n\n Minute-level data included steps, METs, and mean intensity score (0 = sedentary, 3 = vigorous) for overall reported exercise bouts (N=120) and by exercise type (walking, n=16; run or sports, n=44; cardio machine, n=20).\n\n\nResults\nMeasures of steps were similar between devices for average day- and minute-level observations (all P values &gt; .\n\n05).\n\n Fitbit significantly overestimated METs for average daily activity, for overall minutes of reported exercise bouts, and for walking and run or sports exercises (mean difference 0.70, 1.80, 3.16, and 2.00 METs, respectively; all P values &lt; .\n\n001).\n\n For average daily activity, Fitbit significantly underestimated the proportion of time in sedentary and light intensity by 20% and 34%, respectively, and overestimated time by 3% in both moderate and vigorous intensity (all P values &lt; .\n\n001).\n\n Mean intensity scores were not different for overall minutes of exercise or for run or sports and cardio-machine exercises (all P values &gt; .\n\n05).\n\n\nConclusions\nFitbit Flex provides accurate measures of steps for daily activity and minutes of reported exercise, regardless of exercise type.\n\n Although the proportion of time in different intensity levels varied between devices, examining the mean intensity score for minute-level bouts across different exercise types enabled interdevice comparisons that revealed similar measures of exercise intensity.\n\n Fitbit Flex is shown to have measurement limitations that may affect its potential utility and validity for measuring PA attributes in free-living conditions.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5048058","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Gunther","surname":"Eysenbach","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Sheri","surname":"Hartman","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Sheri","surname":"Hartman","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Robert","surname":"Furberg","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Gregory adolescents with ADHD.\n Mobile health (mHealth) technology and social media constitute promising interactive modalities for engaging adolescents—who are at highest risk for ADHD treatment drop-out—in interventions to increase PA.\n The current pilot study evaluated feasibility and acceptability of an innovative intervention incorporating an mHealth-linked wearable activity tracker (Fitbit Flex) and a Facebook group to increase PA among adolescents with ADHD.\n 11 adolescents diagnosed with ADHD (age 14–18, m = 15.5; 54% female) participated in a 4-week trial utilizing the Fitbit Flex in trackers","abstract":"Background\nActivity trackers can potentially stimulate users to increase their physical activity behavior.\n\n The aim of this study was to examine the reliability and validity of ten consumer activity trackers for measuring step count in both laboratory and free-living conditions.\n\n\nMethod\nHealthy adult volunteers (n?=?33) walked twice on a treadmill (4.8 km/h) for 30 min while wearing ten different activity trackers (i.\n\ne.\n\n Lumoback, Fitbit Flex, Jawbone Up, Nike+?Fuelband SE, Misfit Shine, Withings Pulse, Fitbit Zip, Omron HJ-203, Yamax Digiwalker SW-200 and Moves mobile application).\n\n In free-living conditions, 56 volunteers wore the same activity trackers for one working day.\n\n Test-retest reliability was analyzed with the Intraclass Correlation Coefficient (ICC).\n\n Validity was evaluated by comparing each tracker with the gold standard (Optogait system for laboratory and ActivPAL for free-living conditions), using paired samples t-tests, mean absolute percentage errors, correlations and Bland-Altman plots.\n\n\nResults\nTest-retest analysis revealed high reliability for most trackers except for the Omron (ICC .\n\n14), Moves app (ICC .\n\n37) and Nike+?Fuelband (ICC .\n\n53).\n\n The mean absolute percentage errors of the trackers in laboratory and free-living conditions respectively, were: Lumoback (?0.2, ?0.4), Fibit Flex (?5.7, 3.7), Jawbone Up (?1.0, 1.4), Nike+?Fuelband (?18, ?24), Misfit Shine (0.2, 1.1), Withings Pulse (?0.5, ?7.9), Fitbit Zip (?0.3, 1.2), Omron (2.5, ?0.4), Digiwalker (?1.2, ?5.9), and Moves app (9.6, ?37.6).\n\n Bland-Altman plots demonstrated that the limits of agreement varied from 46 steps (Fitbit Zip) to 2422 steps (Nike+?Fuelband) in the laboratory condition, and 866 steps (Fitbit Zip) to 5150 steps (Moves app) in the free-living condition.\n\n\nConclusion\nThe reliability and validity of most trackers for measuring step count is good.\n\n The Fitbit Zip is Measures from Four Personal Health Monitoring Devices Compared to Research-Based Actigraphy and Polysomnography","abstract":"Polysomnography (PSG) is the “gold standard” for monitoring sleep.\n Alternatives to PSG are of interest for clinical, research, and personal use.\n Wrist-worn actigraph devices have been utilized in research settings for measures of sleep for over two decades.\n Whether sleep measures from commercially available devices are similarly valid is unknown.\n We sought to determine the validity of five wearable devices: Basis Health Tracker, Misfit Shine, Fitbit Flex, Withings Pulse O2, and a research-based actigraph, Actiwatch Spectrum.\n We used Wilcoxon Signed Rank tests to assess differences between devices relative to PSG and correlational analysis to assess the strength of the relationship.\n Data loss was greatest for Fitbit and Misfit.\n For all devices, we found no difference and strong correlation of total sleep time with PSG.\n Sleep efficiency differed from PSG for Withings, Misfit, Fitbit, and Basis, while Actiwatch mean values did not differ from that of PSG.\n Only mean values of sleep efficiency (time asleep/time in bed) from Actiwatch correlated with PSG, yet this correlation was weak.\n Light sleep time differed from PSG (nREM1 + nREM2) for all devices.\n Measures of Deep sleep time did not differ from PSG (SWS + REM) for Basis.\n These results reveal the current strengths and limitations in sleep estimates produced by personal health monitoring devices and point to a need for future Efficacy of an Innovative Mobile Phone Technology-Based Intervention for Weight Management for Overweight and Obese Adolescents: Pilot Study","abstract":"Background\nIn the United States, approximately one-third of adolescents are now overweight or obese, and one in six is obese.\n\n This financial cost and the larger nonfinancial costs of obesity make obesity prevention and management for adolescents imperative for the health of the nation.\n\n However, primary care visits are typically brief, and primary care providers may lack adequate resources to help overweight or obese adolescents to manage weight issues.\n\n To augment the efficacy of primary care visits for adolescent weight management, mobile phone technology can be used as an adjunct treatment that provides additional opportunities for encouraging improvement in lifestyle, attainment, and maintenance of healthy weight.\n\n\nObjective\nThe purposes of this study were to (1) measure effects of an innovative mobile phone technology-based intervention for overweight and obese adolescents and to (2) examine the intervention’s feasibility for use in primary care clinics.\n\n\nMethods\nThe mobile phone-based intervention had three components: use of the Fitbit Flex, participation in an online educational program, and receipt of biweekly text messages during the maintenance phase.\n\n A randomized controlled study design was utilized.\n\n Data regarding anthropometrics (body mass index [BMI] and waist-to-hip ratio), blood pressure, levels of physical and sedentary activity, diet, and self-efficacy regarding physical activity and diet were collected at baseline and at 3 and 6 months after the baseline assessment.\n\n\nResults\nA total of 40 adolescents participated in the study.\n\n At the 6-month follow-up visit, compared to participants in the control group, the mobile phone-based intervention participants had significant improvement in BMI (z=–4.37, P=.\n\n001), diastolic blood pressure (z=–3.23, P=.\n\n001), physical activity days per week (z=2.58, P=.\n\n01), TV and computer time (z=–3.34, P=.\n\n001), servings of fruits and vegetables per day (z=2.74, effect sizes were found in these outcome variables.\n\n\nConclusions\nThe use of mobile technologies may offer a practical, reliable adjunct to weight management for overweight and obese adolescents E","surname":"Lung","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1186/s12877-016-0232-3","date":"2016-02-25","title":"Unravelling the potential mechanisms behind hospitalization-associated disability in older patients; the Hospital-Associated Disability and impact on daily Life (Hospital-ADL) cohort study protocol","abstract":"Background\nOver 30 % of older patients experience hospitalization-associated disability (HAD) (i.\n\ne.\n\n, loss of independence in Activities of Daily Living (ADLs)) after an acute hospitalization.\n\n Despite its high prevalence, the mechanisms that underlie HAD remain elusive.\n\n This paper describes the protocol for the Hospital-Associated Disability and impact on daily Life (Hospital-ADL) study, which aims to unravel the potential mechanisms behind HAD from admission to three months post-discharge.\n\n\nMethods/design\nThe Hospital-ADL study is a multicenter, observational, prospective cohort study aiming to recruit 400 patients aged ?70 years that are acutely hospitalized at departments of Internal Medicine, Cardiology or Geriatrics, involving six hospitals in the Netherlands.\n\n Eligible are patients hospitalized for at least 48 h, without major cognitive impairment (Mini Mental State Examination score ?15), who have a life expectancy of more than three months, and without disablement in all six ADLs.\n\n The study will assess possible cognitive, behavioral, psychosocial, physical, and biological factors of HAD.\n\n Data will be collected through: 1] medical and demographical data; 2] personal interviews, which includes assessment of cognitive impairment, behavioral and psychosocial functioning, physical functioning, and health care utilization; 3] physical performance tests, which includes gait speed, hand grip strength, balance, bioelectrical impedance analysis (BIA), and an activity tracker (Fitbit Flex), and; 4] analyses of blood samples to assess inflammatory and metabolic markers.\n\n The primary endpoint is additional disabilities in ADLs three months post-hospital discharge compared to ADL function two weeks prior to hospital admission.\n\n Secondary outcomes are health care utilization, health-related quality of life (HRQoL), physical performance tests, and mortality.\n\n There will be at least five data collection points; within 48 h after admission (H1), at discharge (H3), and at one (P1; home visit), two (P2; by telephone) and three months (P3; home visit) post-discharge.\n\n If the patient is admitted for more than five days, additional measurements will be planned during hospitalization on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday (H2).\n\n\nDiscussion\nThe Hospital-ADL study will provide information on cognitive, behavioral, psychosocial, physical, and biological factors associated with HAD and will be collected during and following hospitalization.\n\n These data may inform new interventions to prevent or restore hospitalization-associated disability.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4779575","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Lucienne found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/s13104-016-2020-8","date":"2016-04-01","title":"Validation of the Fitbit One<sup>®</sup> for physical activity measurement at an upper torso attachment site","abstract":"Background\nThe upper torso is recommended as an attachment site for the Fitbit One®, one of the most common wireless physical activity trackers in the consumer market, and could represent a viable alternative to wrist- and hip-attachment sites.\n\n The objective of this study was to provide evidence concerning the validity of the Fitbit One® attached to the upper torso for measuring step counts and energy expenditure among female adults.\n\n\nResults\nThirteen female adults completed a four-phase treadmill exercise protocol (1.9, 3.0, 4.0, and 5.2 mph).\n\n Participants were fitted with three Fitbit® trackers (two Fitbit One® trackers: one on the upper torso, one on the hip; and a wrist-based Fitbit Flex®).\n\n Steps were assessed by manual counting of a video recording.\n\n Energy expenditure was measured by gas exchange indirect calorimetry.\n\n Concordance correlation coefficients of Fitbit-estimated step counts to observed step counts for the upper torso-attached Fitbit One®, hip-attached Fitbit One® and wrist-attached Fitbit Flex® were 0.98 (95 % CI 0.97–0.99), 0.99 (95 % CI 0.99–0.99), and 0.75 (95 % CI 0.70–0.79), respectively.\n\n The percent error for step count estimates from the upper torso attachment site was ?3 % for all walking and running speeds.\n\n Upper torso step count estimates showed similar accuracy relative to hip attachment of the Fitbit One® and were more accurate than the wrist-based Fitbit Flex®.\n\n Similar results were obtained for energy expenditure estimates.\n\n Energy expenditure estimates for the upper torso attachment site yielded relative percent errors that ranged from 9 to 19 % and were more accurate than the wrist-based Fitbit Flex®, but less accurate than hip attachment of the Fitbit One®.\n\n\nConclusions\nOur study shows that physical activity measures obtained from the upper torso attachment site of the Fitbit One® are accurate across different walking and running speeds in female adults.\n\n The upper torso attachment site of the Fitbit One® outperformed the wrist-based Fitbit Flex® and yielded similar step count estimates to hip-attachment.\n\n These data support the upper torso as an alternative attachment site for the Fitbit One®.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4828816","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Keith W.","surname":"Davidson","email":"kd2124@cumc.columbia.edu","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0161224","date":"2016-08-02","title":"Validity and Reliability of Fitbit Flex for Step Count, Moderate to Vigorous Physical Activity and Activity Energy Expenditure","abstract":"Objectives\nTo examine the validity and reliability of the Fitbit Flex against direct observation for measuring steps in the laboratory and against the Actigraph for step counts in free-living conditions and for moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) and activity energy expenditure (AEE) overall.\n\n\nMethods\nTwenty-five adults (12 females, 13 males) wore a Fitbit Flex and an Actigraph GT3X+ during a laboratory based protocol (including walking, incline walking, running and stepping) and free-living conditions during a single day period to examine measurement of steps, AEE and MVPA.\n\n Twenty-four of the participants attended a second session using the same protocol.\n\n\nResults\nIntraclass correlations (ICC) for test-retest reliability of the Fitbit Flex were strong for walking (ICC = 0.57), moderate for stair stepping (ICC = 0.34), and weak for incline walking (ICC = 0.22) and jogging (ICC = 0.26).\n\n The Fitbit significantly undercounted walking steps in the laboratory (absolute proportional difference: 21.2%, 95%CI 13.0–29.4%), but it was more accurate, despite slightly over counting, for both jogging (6.4%, 95%CI 3.7–9.0%) and stair stepping (15.5%, 95%CI 10.1–20.9%).\n\n The Fitbit had higher coefficients of variation (Cv) for step counts compared to direct observation and the Actigraph.\n\n In free-living conditions, the average MVPA minutes were lower in the Fitbit (35.4 minutes) compared to the Actigraph (54.6 minutes), but AEE was greater from the Fitbit (808.1 calories) versus the Actigraph (538.9 calories).\n\n The coefficients of variation were similar for AEE for the Actigraph (Cv = 36.0) and Fitbit (Cv = 35.0), but lower in the Actigraph (Cv = 25.5) for MVPA against the Fitbit (Cv = 32.7).\n\n\nConclusion\nThe Fitbit Flex has moderate validity for measuring physical activity relative to direct observation and the Actigraph.\n\n Test-rest reliability of the Fitbit was dependant on activity type and had greater variation between sessions compared to the Actigraph.\n\n Physical activity surveillance studies using the Fitbit Flex should consider the potential effect of measurement reactivity and undercounting of steps.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5010194","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Ashleigh","surname":"Sushames","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Andrew","surname":"Edwards","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Fintan","surname":"Thompson","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Robyn","surname":"McDermott","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Klaus","surname":"Gebel","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Maciej","surname":"Buchowski","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Maciej","surname":"Buchowski","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1016/j.jpsychores.2017.03.009","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Validity Position on Pedometer Accuracy at Various Walking Speeds: A Comparative Study","abstract":"Background\nDemographic growth in conjunction with the rise of chronic diseases is increasing the pressure on health care systems in most OECD countries.\n\n Physical activity is known to be an essential factor in improving or maintaining good health.\n\n Walking is especially recommended, as it is an activity that can easily be performed by most people without constraints.\n\n Pedometers have been extensively used as an incentive to motivate people to become more active.\n\n However, a recognized problem with these devices is their diminishing accuracy associated with decreased walking speed.\n\n The arrival on the consumer market of new devices, worn indifferently either at the waist, wrist, or as a necklace, gives rise to new questions regarding their accuracy at these different positions.\n\n\nObjective\nOur objective was to assess the performance of 4 pedometers (iHealth activity monitor, Withings Pulse O2, Misfit Shine, and Garmin vívofit) and compare their accuracy according to their position worn, and at various walking speeds.\n\n\nMethods\nWe conducted this study in a controlled environment with 21 healthy adults required to walk 100 m at 3 different paces (0.4 m/s, 0.6 m/s, and 0.8 m/s) regulated by means of a string attached between their legs at the level of their ankles and a metronome ticking the cadence.\n\n To obtain baseline values, we asked the participants to walk 200 m at their own pace.\n\n\nResults\nA decrease of accuracy was positively correlated with reduced speed for all pedometers (12% mean error at self-selected pace, 27% mean error at 0.8 m/s, 52% mean error at 0.6 m/s, and 76% mean error at 0.4 m/s).\n\n Although the position of the pedometer on the person did not significantly influence its accuracy, some interesting tendencies can be highlighted in 2 settings: (1) positioning the pedometer at the waist at a speed greater than 0.8 m/s or as a necklace at preferred speed tended to produce lower mean errors than at the wrist position; and (2) at a slow speed (0.4 m/s), pedometers worn at the wrist tended to produce a lower mean error than in the other positions.\n\n\nConclusions\nAt all positions, all tested pedometers generated significant errors at slow speeds and therefore cannot be used reliably to evaluate the amount of physical activity for people walking slower than 0.6 m/s (2.16 km/h, or 1.24 mph).\n\n At slow speeds, the better accuracy observed with pedometers worn at the wrist could constitute a valuable line of inquiry for the future development of devices adapted to elderly people.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5073206","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Gunther","surname":"Eysenbach","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Lena","surname":"Griebel","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Lena","surname":"Griebel","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Rosanne","surname":"Freak-Poli","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Pamela","surname":"Elliott","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Frederic","surname":"Ehrler","email":"frederic.ehrler@hcuge.ch","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Frederic","surname":"Ehrler","email":"frederic.ehrler@hcuge.ch","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Chloé","surname":"Weber","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Chloé","surname":"Weber","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Christian","surname":"Lovis","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Christian","surname":"Lovis","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1515/hukin-2015-0170","date":"1970-01-01","title":"The influence of the gait-related arm swing on elevation gain measured by sport watches","abstract":"The elevation gain is an important contributor to the total workload in endurance sports.\n The purpose of this study was to evaluate the influence of the arm swing on elevation gain in three sport watches (Garmin® Forerunner 910XT, Polar® RS800CX and Suunto® Ambit2) on a flat 400 m outdoor track.\n Altogether, a total of 120 repetitions of 1,200 m were performed at self-selected speeds corresponding to strolling, walking, jogging and running.\n During the assessment two devices of each sport watch, one secured on the hip and one on the wrist, were worn by the participants.\n A small but significant (effect size = .\n39; p &lt; .\n001) influence of the arm swing on elevation was revealed in all sport watches.\n Elevation indication errors recorded on the wrist were significantly larger than the ones recorded on the hip (4.0-7.4 vs.\n 1.2-5.7 m per 1,200 m; p &lt; .\n05).\n Furthermore, when wearing the devices on the wrist, errors in elevation indication increased when gait speed increased.\n Users should be aware that wearing the devices on the hip can significantly decrease measurement errors.\n This might be especially relevant for activities with high dynamics, such as jogging and running.\n","id":"PMC5260550","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Rahel","surname":"Ammann","email":"Rahel.Ammann@baspo.admin.ch","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Wolfgang","surname":"Taube","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Matthias","surname":"Neuhaus","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Thomas","surname":"Wyss","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"NULL","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Physical Made for Walking: Sensitivity Performance Evaluation of Commercial Activity Monitors under the Expected Conditions and Circumstances Required to Achieve the International Daily Step Goal of 10,000 Steps","abstract":"Introduction\nPhysical activity is a vitally important part of a healthy lifestyle, and is of major benefit to both physical and mental health.\n\n A daily step count of 10,000 steps is recommended globally to achieve an appropriate level of physical activity.\n\n Accurate quantification of physical activity during conditions reflecting those needed to achieve the recommended daily step count of 10,000 steps is essential.\n\n As such, we aimed to assess four commercial activity monitors for their sensitivity/accuracy in a prescribed walking route that reflects a range of surfaces that would typically be used to achieve the recommended daily step count, in two types of footwear expected to be used throughout the day when aiming to achieve the recommended daily step count, and in a timeframe required to do so.\n\n\nMethods\nFour commercial activity monitors were worn simultaneously by participants (n = 15) during a prescribed walking route reflective of surfaces typically encountered while achieving the daily recommended 10,000 steps.\n\n Activity monitors tested were the Garmin Vivofit ™, New Lifestyles’ NL-2000 ™ pedometer, Withings Smart Activity Monitor Tracker (Pulse O2) ™, and Fitbit One ™.\n\n\nResults\nAll activity monitors tested were accurate in their step detection over the variety of different surfaces tested (natural lawn grass, gravel, ceramic tile, tarmacadam/asphalt, linoleum), when wearing both running shoes and hard-soled dress shoes.\n\n\nConclusion\nAll activity monitors tested were accurate in their step detection sensitivity and are valid monitors for physical activity quantification over the variety of different surfaces tested, when wearing both running shoes and hard-soled dress shoes, and over a timeframe necessary for accumulating the recommended daily step count of 10,000 steps.\n\n However, it is important to consider the accuracy of activity monitors, particularly when physical activity in the form of stepping activities is prescribed as an intervention in the treatment or prevention of a disease state.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4864247","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Sandra","surname":"O’Connell","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Gearóid","surname":"ÓLaighin","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Lisa","surname":"Kelly","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Elaine","surname":"Murphy","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Sorcha","surname":"Beirne","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Niall","surname":"Burke","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Orlaith","surname":"Kilgannon","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Leo found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1136/openhrt-2015-000373","date":"2015-12-14","title":"Heart rate never lies: interventional cardiologist and Braude's quote revised","abstract":"Background\nInterventional cardiologists may be immune to stress, allowing them to perform complex percutaneous interventions under pressure.\n\n\nObjectives\nTo assess heart rate (HR) variations as a surrogate marker of stress of interventional cardiologists during percutaneous cardiac procedures and in every-day life.\n\n\nDesign\nThis is a single-centre observational study including a total of six male interventional cardiologists performing coronary interventions and pacemaker implantations.\n\n Participants were asked to record their HR with the Apple Watch Device during procedures, every-day life and control activities such as outpatient consultations, sport, marital conflicts and sexual intercourse.\n\n\nResults\nAverage daily HR was 88±17?bpm.\n\n During work days, HR increased significantly during procedures (90±17?bpm) compared with days outside the cathlab (87±17?bpm, p=0.02).\n\n The average HR was higher during a regular week working (88±16?bpm) compared with weekends off (84±18?bpm, p=0.002).\n\n Complex cardiac procedures were associated with higher HR up to 122?bpm.\n\n Peak HR were higher during physical exertion.\n\n Of note, participants complained of hypersexuality and mania after night shifts.\n\n\nConclusions\nWork and especially percutaneous cardiac procedures increase HR independently of physical exertion suggesting that interventional cardiologists experience mental stress and emotions.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4716451","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Stéphane","surname":"Cook","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jean-Christophe","surname":"Stauffer","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jean-Jacques","surname":"Goy","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Denis","surname":"Graf","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Serban","surname":"Puricel","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Aurélien","surname":"Frobert","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Olivier","surname":"Muller","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Mario","surname":"Togni","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Diego","surname":"Arroyo","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.2196/mhealth.4225","date":"2015-11-05","title":"Acceptance of Commercially Available Wearable Activity Trackers Among Adults Aged Over 50 and With Chronic Illness: A Mixed-Methods Evaluation","abstract":"Background\nPhysical inactivity and sedentary behavior increase the risk of chronic illness and death.\n\n The newest generation of “wearable” activity trackers offers potential as a multifaceted intervention to help people become more active.\n\n\nObjective\nTo examine the usability and usefulness of wearable activity trackers for older adults living with chronic illness.\n\n\nMethods\nWe recruited a purposive sample of 32 participants over the age of 50, who had been previously diagnosed with a chronic illness, including vascular disease, diabetes, arthritis, and osteoporosis.\n\n Participants were between 52 and 84 years of age (mean 64); among the study participants, 23 (72%) were women and the mean body mass index was 31 kg/m2.\n\n Participants tested 5 trackers, including a simple pedometer (Sportline or Mio) followed by 4 wearable activity trackers (Fitbit Zip, Misfit Shine, Jawbone Up 24, and Withings Pulse) in random order.\n\n Selected devices represented the range of wearable products and features available on the Canadian market in 2014. Participants wore each device for at least 3 days and evaluated it using a questionnaire developed from the Technology Acceptance Model.\n\n We used focus groups to explore participant experiences and a thematic analysis approach to data collection and analysis.\n\n\nResults\nOur study resulted in 4 themes: (1) adoption within a comfort zone; (2) self-awareness and goal setting; (3) purposes of data tracking; and (4) future of wearable activity trackers as health care devices.\n\n Prior to enrolling, few participants were aware of wearable activity trackers.\n\n Most also had been asked by a physician to exercise more and cited this as a motivation for testing the devices.\n\n None of the participants planned to purchase the simple pedometer after the study, citing poor accuracy and data loss, whereas 73% (N=32) planned to purchase a wearable activity tracker.\n\n Preferences varied but 50% felt they would buy a Fitbit and 42% felt they would buy a Misfit, Jawbone, or Withings.\n\n The simple pedometer had a mean acceptance score of 56/95 compared with 63 for the Withings, 65 for the Misfit and Jawbone, and 68 for the Fitbit.\n\n To improve usability, older users may benefit from devices that have better compatibility with personal computers or less-expensive Android mobile phones and tablets, and have comprehensive paper-based user manuals and apps that interpret user data.\n\n\nConclusions\nFor older adults living with chronic illness, wearable activity trackers are perceived as useful and acceptable.\n\n New users may need support to both set up the device and learn how to interpret their data.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4749845","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Gunther","surname":"Eysenbach","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Elizabeth","surname":"Lyons","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Elizabeth","surname":"Lyons","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Carmen","surname":"Poon","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Lex","surname":"van Currently Available Wearable Devices for Activity Tracking and Heart Rate Monitoring Accurate, Precise, and Medically Beneficial?","abstract":"Objectives\nThe new wave of wireless technologies, fitness trackers, and body sensor devices can have great impact on healthcare systems and the quality of life.\n\n However, there have not been enough studies to prove the accuracy and precision of these trackers.\n\n The objective of this study was to evaluate the accuracy, precision, and overall performance of seventeen wearable devices currently available compared with direct observation of step counts and heart rate monitoring.\n\n\nMethods\nEach participant in this study used three accelerometers at a time, running the three corresponding applications of each tracker on an Android or iOS device simultaneously.\n\n Each participant was instructed to walk 200, 500, and 1,000 steps.\n\n Each set was repeated 40 times.\n\n Data was recorded after each trial, and the mean step count, standard deviation, accuracy, and precision were estimated for each tracker.\n\n Heart rate was measured by all trackers (if applicable), which support heart rate monitoring, and compared to a positive control, the Onyx Vantage 9590 professional clinical pulse oximeter.\n\n\nResults\nThe accuracy of the tested products ranged between 79.8% and 99.1%, while the coefficient of variation (precision) ranged between 4% and 17.5%.\n\n MisFit Shine showed the highest accuracy and precision (along with Qualcomm Toq), while Samsung Gear 2 showed the lowest accuracy, and Jawbone UP showed the lowest precision.\n\n However, Xiaomi Mi band showed the best package compared to its price.\n\n\nConclusions\nThe accuracy and precision of the selected fitness trackers are reasonable and can indicate the average level of activity and thus average energy expenditure.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4659890","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Fatema","surname":"El-Amrawy","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Mohamed Ismail","surname":"Nounou","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1186/s12966-015-0201-9","date":"2015-03-09","title":"The validity of consumer-level, activity monitors in healthy adults worn in free-living conditions: a cross-sectional study","abstract":"Background\nTechnological advances have seen a burgeoning industry for accelerometer-based wearable activity monitors targeted at the consumer market.\n\n The purpose of this study was to determine the convergent validity of a selection of consumer-level accelerometer-based activity monitors.\n\n\nMethods\n21 healthy adults wore seven consumer-level activity monitors (Fitbit One, Fitbit Zip, Jawbone UP, Misfit Shine, Nike Fuelband, Striiv Smart Pedometer and Withings Pulse) and two research-grade accelerometers/multi-sensor devices (BodyMedia SenseWear, and ActiGraph GT3X+) for 48-hours.\n\n Participants went about their daily life in free-living conditions during data collection.\n\n The validity of the consumer-level activity monitors relative to the research devices for step count, moderate to vigorous physical activity (MVPA), sleep and total daily energy expenditure (TDEE) was quantified using Bland-Altman analysis, median absolute difference and Pearson’s correlation.\n\n\nResults\nAll consumer-level activity monitors correlated strongly (r?&gt;?0.8) with research-grade devices for step count and sleep time, but only moderately-to-strongly for TDEE (r?=?0.74-0.81) and MVPA (r?=?0.52-0.91).\n\n Median absolute differences were generally modest for sleep and steps (&lt;10% of research device mean values for the majority of devices) moderate for TDEE (&lt;30% of research device mean values), and large for MVPA (26-298%).\n\n Across the constructs examined, the Fitbit One, Fitbit Zip and Withings Pulse performed most strongly.\n\n\nConclusions\nIn free-living conditions, the consumer-level activity monitors showed strong validity for the measurement of steps and sleep duration, and moderate valid for measurement of TDEE and MVPA.\n\n Validity for each construct ranged widely between devices, with the Fitbit One, Fitbit Zip and Withings Pulse being the strongest performers.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4416251","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Ty","surname":"Ferguson","email":"ferty02f@mymail.unisa.edu.au","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Alex found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1007/s00421-015-3303-9","date":"2015-11-18","title":"Validity of the Polar V800 heart rate monitor to measure RR intervals at rest","abstract":"Purpose\nTo assess the validity of RR intervals and short-term heart rate variability (HRV) data obtained from the Polar V800 heart rate monitor, in comparison to an electrocardiograph (ECG).\n\n\nMethod\nTwenty participants completed an active orthostatic test using the V800 and ECG.\n\n An improved method for the identification and correction of RR intervals was employed prior to HRV analysis.\n\n Agreement of the data was assessed using intra-class correlation coefficients (ICC), Bland–Altman limits of agreement (LoA), and effect size (ES).\n\n\nResults\nA small number of errors were detected between ECG and Polar RR signal, with a combined error rate of 0.086 %.\n\n The RR intervals from ECG to V800 were significantly different, but with small ES for both supine corrected and standing corrected data (ES &lt;0.001).\n\n The bias (LoA) were 0.06 (?4.33 to 4.45 ms) and 0.59 (?1.70 to 2.87 ms) for supine and standing intervals, respectively.\n\n The ICC was &gt;0.999 for both supine and standing corrected intervals.\n\n When analysed with the same HRV software no significant differences were observed in any HRV parameters, for either supine or standing; the data displayed small bias and tight LoA, strong ICC (&gt;0.99) and small ES (?0.029).\n\n\nConclusions\nThe V800 improves over previous Polar models, with narrower LoA, stronger ICC and smaller ES for both the RR intervals and HRV parameters.\n\n The findings support the validity of the Polar V800 and its ability to produce RR interval recordings consistent with an ECG.\n\n In addition, HRV parameters derived from these recordings are also highly comparable.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4751190","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"David","surname":"Giles","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Nick","surname":"Draper","email":"n.draper@derby.ac.uk","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"William","surname":"Neil","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1016/j.ijmedinf.2017.03.008","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Reliability found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0169616","date":"2016-12-19","title":"When a Step Is Not a Step! Specificity Analysis of Five Physical Activity Monitors","abstract":"Introduction\nPhysical activity is an essential aspect of a healthy lifestyle for both physical and mental health states.\n\n As step count is one of the most utilized measures for quantifying physical activity it is important that activity-monitoring devices be both sensitive and specific in recording actual steps taken and disregard non-stepping body movements.\n\n The objective of this study was to assess the specificity of five activity monitors during a variety of prescribed non-stepping activities.\n\n\nMethods\nParticipants wore five activity monitors simultaneously for a variety of prescribed activities including deskwork, taking an elevator, taking a bus journey, automobile driving, washing and drying dishes; functional reaching task; indoor cycling; outdoor cycling; and indoor rowing.\n\n Each task was carried out for either a specific duration of time or over a specific distance.\n\n Activity monitors tested were the ActivPAL micro™, NL-2000™ pedometer, Withings Smart Activity Monitor Tracker (Pulse O2)™, Fitbit One™ and Jawbone UP™.\n\n Participants were video-recorded while carrying out the prescribed activities and the false positive step count registered on each activity monitor was obtained and compared to the video.\n\n\nResults\nAll activity monitors registered a significant number of false positive steps per minute during one or more of the prescribed activities.\n\n The Withings™ activity performed best, registering a significant number of false positive steps per minute during the outdoor cycling activity only (P = 0.025).\n\n The Jawbone™ registered a significant number of false positive steps during the functional reaching task and while washing and drying dishes, which involved arm and hand movement (P &lt; 0.01 for both).\n\n The ActivPAL™ registered a significant number of false positive steps during the cycling exercises (P &lt; 0.001 for both).\n\n\nConclusion\nAs a number of false positive steps were registered on the activity monitors during the non-stepping activities, the authors conclude that non-stepping physical activities can result in the false detection of steps.\n\n This can negatively affect the quantification of physical activity with regard to step count as an output.\n\n The Withings™ activity monitor performed best with regard to specificity during the activities of daily living tested.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5234787","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Sandra","surname":"O’Connell","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Gearóid","surname":"ÓLaighin","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Leo photopletysmography","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.3109/03091902.2015.1047536","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Validation of photoplethysmography as a method to detect heart rate during rest and exercise","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.2196/mhealth.7437","date":"2017-05-10","title":"Estimating Heart Rate, Energy Expenditure, and Physical Performance With a Wrist Photoplethysmographic Device During Running","abstract":"Background\nWearable sensors enable long-term monitoring of health and wellbeing indicators.\n\n An objective evaluation of sensors’ accuracy is important, especially for their use in health care.\n\n\nObjective\nThe aim of this study was to use a wrist-worn optical heart rate (OHR) device to estimate heart rate (HR), energy expenditure (EE), and maximal oxygen intake capacity (VO2Max) during running and to evaluate the accuracy of the estimated parameters (HR, EE, and VO2Max) against golden reference methods.\n\n\nMethods\nA total of 24 healthy volunteers, of whom 11 were female, with a mean age of 36.2 years (SD 8.2 years) participated in a submaximal self-paced outdoor running test and maximal voluntary exercise test in a sports laboratory.\n\n OHR was monitored with a PulseOn wrist-worn photoplethysmographic device and the running speed with a phone GPS sensor.\n\n A physiological model based on HR, running speed, and personal characteristics (age, gender, weight, and height) was used to estimate EE during the maximal voluntary exercise test and VO2Max during the submaximal outdoor running test.\n\n ECG-based HR and respiratory gas analysis based estimates were used as golden references.\n\n\nResults\nOHR was able to measure HR during running with a 1.9% mean absolute percentage error (MAPE).\n\n VO2Max estimated during the submaximal outdoor running test was closely similar to the sports laboratory estimate (MAPE 5.2%).\n\n The energy expenditure estimate (n=23) was quite accurate when HR was above the aerobic threshold (MAPE 6.7%), but MAPE increased to 16.5% during a lighter intensity of exercise.\n\n\nConclusions\nThe results suggest that wrist-worn OHR may accurately estimate HR during running up to maximal HR.\n\n When combined with physiological modeling, wrist-worn OHR may be used for an estimation of EE, especially during higher intensity running, and VO2Max, even during submaximal self-paced outdoor recreational promoting HPV vaccination depend on accurate surveys of public awareness and knowledge of HPV and related sexual behavior.\n\n However, the most recent population-based studies have relied largely on computer-assisted telephone interviews (CATI) as opposed to face to face interviews (FTFI).\n\n It is currently unknown how these survey modes differ, and in particular whether they attract similar demographics and therefore lead to similar overall findings.\n\n\nMethods\nA comprehensive survey of HPV awareness and knowledge, including sexual behavior, was conducted among 3,045 Singaporean men and women, half of whom participated via CATI, the other half via FTFI.\n\n\nResults\nOverall levels of awareness and knowledge of HPV differed between CATI and FTFI, attributable in part to demographic variations between these survey modes.\n\n Although disclosure of sexual behavior was greater when using CATI, few differences between survey modes were found in the actual information disclosed.\n\n\nConclusion\nAlthough CATI is a cheaper, faster alternative to FTFI and people appear more willing to provide information about sexual behavior when surveyed using CATI, thorough questionnaire, the mean age was 45 years, 67% were female, and 65% had college or university degree.\n\n Eighty-six percent of women had undergone at least one Pap-test in their life, 55% in the last year, and 15% from 1 to 3 years ago.\n\n Among screened women, the test had been performed in the last three years in 100% of 18–30 year-olds, but only in 67% of 60–69 year-olds (P &lt; 0.0001).\n\n Only 15% of respondents had heard of HPV.\n\n Eighty-seven percent agreed that HPV vaccines could prevent cervical cancer, 73% that the vaccine has to be administered before the onset of sexual activity, 89% would recommend vaccination to their daughters and nieces.\n\n Among respondents &lt; 25 years, 91% would agree to receive the vaccine if it is publicly funded, but only 72% would agree to pay $100/dose.\n\n\nConclusion\nThere is an important heterogeneity in cervical cancer screening frequency and coverage.\n\n Despite low awareness of HPV infection, the majority of respondents Estimates for nutrients (energy, protein, total fat, saturated fat, carbohydrate, sugars, dietary fibre, and alcohol) and fruit and vegetable servings were compared between methods using correlation coefficients, 95% limits of agreement, and quintile classifications.\n One week later, a second DQESV2 was completed by n?=?77 of the participants to assess reproducibility using intra-class correlations (ICC) and weighted kappa.\n Comparing methods, all nutrients and fruit and vegetable servings showed significant positive correlations (P&lt;0.05) except protein intake in males; over 60% of participants were within one quintile classification except total fat and dietary fibre intakes in males (55% and 56%, respectively); and differences in nutrient and food intakes between methods were all within +/?20% of the mean WFR values except alcohol intake in females.\n Between first and second administrations of the DQESV2 all ICC coefficients were positive (P&lt;0.01) and weighted kappa coefficients ranged from 0.54 for fruit servings (including fruit juice) in males to 0.91 for protein intake in females.\n Over a one month period, the DQESV2 demonstrated good reproducibility for the studied nutrients and for fruit and vegetable servings and provided a valid measure of the studied nutrients, except alcohol in females, and of fruit servings (including fruit juice) in both genders, at the group level in this young adult population.\n","id":"PMC3776736","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Lana","surname":"Hebden","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Engracia","surname":"Kostan","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Fiona","surname":"O’Leary","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Allison","surname":"Hodge","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Margaret","surname":"Allman-Farinelli","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Martyn","surname":"Kirk","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Martyn","surname":"Kirk","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}],"References depth 2":[{"doi":"NULL","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Gibson RS (2005) Validity in dietary assessment methods.
